TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The amendments relate to the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill 1985. At the same time as this Bill was debated in the Senate the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill 1985 was debated in the Senate. We will deal with that Bill later as amendments were also made to it. The amendments to both Bills were moved by the Government and relate to powers of entry, search and seizure. The amendments were prompted by comments of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The Bills passed by this House gave certain powers of entry, search and seizure to police officers when executing a warrant for the apprehension of a fugitive. If a police officer had reasonable grounds for suspecting that there might be upon any land or upon or in any premises, vessel, aircraft or vehicle, evidence in relation to the offences for which extradition had been sought, or any property which had been acquired as a result of such offences, he could enter the land, et cetera, and search for and seize such evidence.

The Senate Committee drew these amendments to the attention of honourable senators on the basis that they may trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. The Committee argued that the right to enter and search buildings and property is usually accompanied by a requirement that a warrant specifically directed to such action be obtained beforehand. I considered that there was merit in the Senate Committee's comments. Certainly clause 37 of the Criminal Investigation Bill, which may be regarded as representing modern processes in this area and which is consistent with common law, permits only the clothing and property under the control of the arrested person to be searched. The amendments which were passed by the Senate replace the existing provisions with provisions which provide that a police officer, in arresting a fugitive, may search only the person and clothing of the fugitive and property under his control for evidence relevant to the extradition crimes, or property acquired as a result of those crimes. Any such evidence or property discovered may then be seized. If there is to be any additional search of land, buildings, et cetera, and seizure of property in evidence, it may be undertaken only pursuant to a warrant issued by the magistrate.

Another amendment to this Bill was moved by Senator Haines. It was not opposed. That amendment was to delete clause 4 of the Bill. The clause inserted a new section 4A which in effect would have enabled the regulations to amend the list of extradictable crimes in the Act to take account of serious new offences created by international conventions. With the deletion of the clause, the list of extradictable offences will have to be amended by statute when such offences are created. Of course, that can be done when the Parliament creates the new offences, and acceptance of the amendment negates any possible criticism that the proposed new section 4A would have involved an undue delegation of legislative power. Accordingly, I have moved that the Committee accept the amendments made by the Senate to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short point to be made is that the Opposition agrees with the Government's motion to accept the proposed amendments to the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill. I must say first of all that it is a thoroughly unsatisfactory situation for this Parliament and its committees to find that when we come into the chamber at 10 o'clock we have, with respect to the two extradition Bills we are concerned with, eight pages of amendments which we are expected to digest, in effect, on the spot. I see that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), to his credit, is nodding in agreement. This is a thoroughly unsatisfactory situation. Whether the Government or somebody else is responsible for it, to be perfectly honest, I do not know. But whoever is responsible for it, it does not reflect much credit on the workings of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We have debated at some length two extradition Bills. The Government and the Opposition had an opportunity to put their views in debate, the Bills went off to the Senate and some amendments were made there. That is the prerogative of the Senate; that is what the Senate, as a House of review, is for. The Bills have now been brought back to this House. That is a sensible way of dealing with legislation but it is completely nonsensical to expect members of this House, either in Committee or in the House, to debate in effect at one minute's notice eight pages of quite complicated legal provisions. Let me place on record the fact that the Opposition is completely dissatisfied with this method of operating the Parliament and Government back benchers should be dissatisfied. No matter what party is in government the affairs of the Parliament should be conducted in a manner so that members of Parliament can understand what is being proposed to change laws whether they be new laws or laws already on the books. I hope that those responsible will endeavour to find a better way of putting such amendments before this chamber than that which has been adopted on this occasion.

The Opposition spokesman in the Senate, Senator Durack, yesterday informed me of the substance of the amendments and the reasons why the Opposition went along with them in the Senate. For that reason, and for that reason alone, the Opposition in this place is prepared to accept what the Government has put. Therefore, we do not oppose the amendments. The substance of the amendments seems to be a proposal for a search warrant to be issued by a magistrate in appropriate cases where appropriate facts are put before him showing that there is a need for a search to take place and a justification for a search warrant to be issued. I suppose that that is in keeping with the times. A speech by Mr Temby yesterday reflected the views of some people that the fight against crime may well have been compromised-if I can use a neutral word-by an excessive concern to get on with the job, in the course of which some civil liberties may have been put at risk. We have always taken the view that there is a balance to be obtained. On the one hand the fight against crime is of enormous importance. On the other hand, the civil liberties of individual citizens must be considered. To that extent one must continue to have regard for the need for machinery such as search warrants, which do exercise some restraint over law enforcement officers-perhaps more restraint than there may otherwise be.

I am concerned about some other aspects of Mr Temby's speech, at least as they were reported in the newspapers, and in particular that he seems to indicate that he is still opposed to indemnities being granted to police officers. I am concerned particularly because the Director of Public Prosecutions has a part to play in the granting of indemnities, at least according to the procedure set out in the Senate by the once and future Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, the other day. I am concerned that the Director of Public Prosecutions seems to have expressed, almost in a sense of some pre-judgment, that he still holds the view that indemnities should not be granted to New South Wales police concerned with phone tapping. I suppose that there will be another occasion on which that matter can be aired and advanced further.

In this case, two substantial amendments are proposed by the Government. As I have said, the Opposition will support those amendments, despite the fact that the manner in which they have been brought into the House and the basis upon which they have been expected to be debated are thoroughly unsatisfactory.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The amendments have come about as a result of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills making recommendations for amendment. We have just dealt with the Extradition (Commonwealth Countries) Amendment Bill. We are now dealing with the Extradition (Foreign States) Amendment Bill. In my previous speech on the first mentioned Bill I said that the Government accepted those amendments which relate to powers of entry, search and seizure. The amendments were prompted by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. The idea was to ensure that there would be warrants issued not only on the question of search, but also if there was going to be search and seizure of property. In other words, further warrants had to be obtained. That applies to this Bill. Accordingly, I do not wish to repeat what I have already said; it is the same principle and we are prepared to accept it. However, there is an additional factor in this amending Bill. The Senate amended the Bill on the basis that clause 4 inserts new section 9 (1A), which creates a Schedule listing the countries to which the Act applies by virtue of the existence of an inherited treaty. The amendment simply provides for a further new section 9 (1B) to the effect that where one of the inherited treaties is replaced by a modern treaty, the reference in the Schedule to the relevant country shall be omitted. The amendment thereby removes the need to amend the Schedule in the Act whenever a modern treaty replaces an inherited treaty. The amendment is, accordingly, of a minor formal nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Messner, who is the shadow Minister for Community Services, I indicate that the Opposition supports the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill. But we feel that certain safeguards are required as far as the Parliament and the Government, particularly the Parliament, are concerned. We will move amendments in the Committee stage of the Bill. The Bill follows the 1984 Budget announcement of the establishment of a co-ordinated supported accommodation assistance scheme. This Bill establishes that program for four and a half years, commencing on 1 January 1985. Basically, for that reason, we say that we support the Bill because, as the appropriation is made under the Bill, we appreciate that there will be confusion if we do not allow it to pass at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill includes a general supported accommodation sub-program for men and women and their dependants who are permanently or temporarily homeless as a result of crisis and who need support towards independent living where possible and appropriate. It also includes a women's emergency services sub-program for women and women with dependent children who are escaping from intolerable domestic circumstances or other crisis situations and who need support to move towards independent living where possible and appropriate. It also includes a youth supported accommodation sub-program for persons 12 to 25 years of age and their dependants who are homeless as a result of crisis and who need support to move towards independent living where possible and appropriate.

The assistance will be provided through non-government organisations and local government. The Commonwealth will guarantee a minimum level of financial assistance. The other proviso is that the States and the Northern Territory will be required to match this in part and as applicable. As far as I know, the extent of that funding has not yet been determined. The agreement of the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory is required to approve funding for particular services under the SAAP. The agreement is detailed in the Schedule and this is where we feel there will need to be some amendment. The program will be administered by the States and the Northern Territory in accordance with jointly agreed national guidelines. As the Opposition's federalism policy is to restore to the States the services that are directly applicable to them, this accords with our policy in that regard. Non-government organisations and local government will be consulted and advice sought for the SAAP needs and priorities. I believe that the form of consultation has yet to be thought right through. I make the comment on this legislation that, as with the home and community care legislation, this degree of consultation will be absolutely necessary if these new programs, which supersede others in part, are to be successful. I have had requests from various community-based organisations that these consultative measures move towards what they require, and not the more rigid and flexible arrangements between the Commonwealth and State governments. I believe it is appropriate that that should be considered.

The Bill appropriates a sum of $17m in this year and an amount of $27m-plus in a full year. It is intended that this funding will be maintained in real terms. But what concerns the Opposition is that, as the continuing review takes place, it will perhaps be necessary from time to time, if additional organisations are to be included within the SAAP program, for additional finance to be provided.

The Bill will consolidate under one program the administration of a number of emergency relief services. One can pass on some of the comments of the organisations that will be affected about where they see a possible need for such consolidation. They argue whether better administration will take place if that consultation process is not maintained at the level of the client group. In theory, we do not oppose the co-ordination and certainly we do not oppose the consultation. As I have said, we agree to the co-ordination in the Bill. But we are concerned that the Parliament is being asked to approve legislation-as I said, the expenditure on a yearly basis is some $27.2m-without the full details of the scheme having yet been finalised. We understand that a review is going on before the guidelines are firmly established. While this Bill makes the appropriation and sets the agreements and the schedules in order, the later amendments or the guidelines will not necessarily be approved by the Parliament; they will be subject to agreement between the Commonwealth and the States.

We are concerned about the status of a number of the organisations which, although originally to be included in the program, have been excluded and are subject to that ongoing review. I believe 67 of the more traditional and larger services that have been excluded from the SAAP will continue to receive funding from the homeless persons assistance program which was originally to be replaced by the SAAP. We believe that the Parliament should be involved in reviewing whether some of these organisations should be excluded. We do not blame the Government for this because we understand that it is an agreement with the States and that it was the recommendation of the States that these be excluded. But what worries the Opposition is that amongst that group of 67 are some fine organisations and institutions that have demonstrated that they are very reliable providers of the services which are funded by both the States and the Commonwealth. I mention the Wesley Central Mission, the Salvation Army with its many centres and the St Vincent de Paul Society. All of these organisations provide services at the moment within the States. I will demonstrate the services of those organisations in my own city of Mackay. I mention the Salvation Army which, through the Good Samaritan House, provides crisis accommodation for women and their children within the city of Mackay. If the original capital for that was not provided, certainly the ongoing maintenance of those services is provided by that organisation. Those functions are being performed on a first class basis. Also, the St Vincent de Paul Society has received funds under the old Act for homeless men and youth but that building has yet to be opened. These two organisations have demonstrated, not only within the city of Mackay but right through Australia, that they can spend the welfare dollar in a much better way than can the Commonwealth and the States. That is very important to remember. So many of these voluntary organisations work in the field. They have a greater expertise than any government can ever hope to achieve. They have experience that social welfare workers in the normal mainstream of life have not yet been able to emulate successfully. The proposition that we will be putting later will be that we hope that we can have a parliamentary review to monitor the review that is going on at the moment by the Government and the States to make sure that funds are provided for these organisations. I ask the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) who is at the table-I am sure that he is well aware of what is required-to ensure that this takes place.

There are two programs, the SAAP program and the home and community care program. It appears to us that the HACC program is being delayed until the guidelines are fully developed. Hopefully, that legislation will come in as a total package. But that delay is still confusing the minds of the intended recipients or the past recipients of the old programs and those who might hope to be funded under the new one. I understand that the Minister took the opportunity at the end of March to go to meetings and seminars within the States to explain the home and community care scheme. While those meetings probably did calm a little the otherwise troubled waters, still no definite guidelines are being reached.

As shadow Minister for Social Security I have been asked what will happen in the case of organisations such as the Blue Nursing Service which are providing some of these facilities at the moment and where will they stand in the future. I understand that under the program there has been a partial disbursement to the States and that some States have already taken up the partial disbursement under the departments of health, not under the departments of welfare. It concerns me that perhaps the guidelines are not as rigidly in place as they might be at this stage.

The SAAP suffers another disadvantage, which is that while we have the Bill, the appropriation and the agreements, a review is still being undertaken as to what organisations will or will not be accepted and what the criteria for acceptance will be. I am reminded of a Senate Estimates committee meeting which took place on 15 April during which the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) and the Department were queried about what might happen in the future and how relaxed the Department might be in connection with amending or monitoring the present situation. TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) when the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill 1985 was introduced into this House, when this Government came to office in March 1983 homelessness was seen as a major priority for urgent attention, and well it might have been. The program itself will provide funds for recurrent and capital non-housing purposes to non-government organisations and local government authorities. I know that the projects which the Western Australian committee has rejected for inclusion under this program are being funded at supported accommodation assistance program levels, by the Commonwealth.

The Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill represents the first concerted attempt by a Commonwealth government to rationalise and improve the many schemes and programs which exist throughout Australia to help people without homes. The Bill is the outcome of nearly 18 months of consultation with the States and the Northern Territory, non-government organisations, advisory bodies and the providers of services to homeless people. I should like to start by congratulating the Hon. Keith Wilson, the Western Australian Minister for Community Services, and all the other people who have been involved in devising the program in Western Australia, my home State, for the constructive and co-operative attitude they have shown during the negotiations.

The Commonwealth has been involved in the provision of assistance to homeless people since 1974. Programs have included the youth services scheme, the family support services scheme, the children's services program, the crisis accommodation for families in distress program, and the homeless persons assistance program. Some of these schemes were administered by the Commonwealth, and others by the States. At the same time, the States were also funding and running other similar schemes. The result was a hotchpotch of legislation in which financial and physical resources were in grave danger of missing their most appropriate and effective mark.

In 1982, the Federal and State Welfare Ministers agreed on the need to review all the Commonwealth and Commonwealth-State programs with the aim or rationalising the co-ordination, the delivery and the general standard of services to the homeless. The review, as the House has already heard from the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), was finally set in motion by this Government early in its first term. It came to be known as the Review of Crisis and Youth Accommodation and was carried out under the auspices of the Departments of Social Security, Housing and Construction, and Education and Youth Affairs. The review found that the existing system was inadequate and illogical, unco-ordinated, complex and poorly funded. It is the recommended remedy to this situation that we are discussing here today.

The Minister's second reading speech contains a concise account of the details of the new arrangements, but I would still like to draw attention to some of the particularly noteworthy points. The key elements of the legislation is its flexibility, and I am pleased to see that this has been acknowledged with approval by the Opposition. The aim is to provide homeless people-that is, people who lack adequate shelter or support from both family and the community-with help in the short, medium and even longer term. The legislation recognises that homeless people have various requirements, from emergency accommodation in a crisis to help with child and health care and financial counselling. Some people need immediate access to short term accommodation and intensive support services such as those found in refuges for women and youths. Others need a less intensive level of support and might be helped by spending time in a halfway house or a hostel.

The three sub-programs which make up the Bill give a clear indication of the breadth of the new arrangements. The first section deals with youth supported accommodation and aims to provide services for young people between the ages of 12 and 25. This area has already been allocated $830,000 in the 1984-85 financial year to cover the first six months of the program. In the 1985-86 full financial year it will attract $1.66m.

The second section involves the women's emergency services program, which was first established by this Government in 1983 with an allocation of $4m. This program will continue to cater for women with and without dependants who need to get out of violent or threatening domestic situations. I will be addressing myself to this section of the Bill a little later.

The third section of the Bill deals with the general supported accommodation program which provides for services to those men, women and children who are permanently or temporarily homeless but who do not fit clearly or practically within the youth or women's supported accommodation program. One of the points which the Minister has stressed about the applicability of this Bill is that the three broad sub-programs extend the range of the program rather than limit it. Women, for instance, may be assisted under any one of the three different sections, depending on the specific needs and problems being catered for. Likewise, services for young people could be eligible for funding under either the women's emergency services program, the youth supported accommodation program, or even, in special circumstances, the general program.

As a Western Australian, I am particularly pleased to be able to report to the House that the Western Australian State Government has accepted the terms and conditions contained in this Bill, and a supported accommodation assistance program began on 1 January this year. The State Minister, Mr Wilson, has also agreed that Western Australia will operate under the national guidelines, and will shortly be advising this Government's Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) about Western Australia's advisory structures. A proposal to allocate $700,000 worth of Commonwealth funds is currently being examined by the Western Australian Commonwealth-State joint committee, and the Federal Government has agreed to continue funding, at levels equivalent to the new program, the eight homeless persons assistance program projects which the State excluded from funding under the new arrangements. Western Australia has also agreed to meet Commonwealth matching requirements by 1988-89. We already have 15 services approved under the youth section programs, 14 approved as women's emergency services and 22 services approved under the general sub-program. New services are currently under consideration for inclusion in all three sub-programs.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I do not want to take up too much of the time of the House. However, I do want to return briefly to the women's emergency services sub-program, and acknowledge some of the work which has been done in this area. As I commented earlier, the Commonwealth has been involved in the provision of assistance to homeless people since 1974, and it was at this time that I first got to know some of the women around this country who were organising refuges for women. Many of them are still involved in refuge work-so their credentials and track records referred to by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Petrie, have truly been set down and established-having spent more than 10 years without adequate funding, without any organisational back-up, and without the human and capital resources so desperately needed. I want to pay tribute to these women, and particularly to the Western Australian refuge workers who have had to battle the odds with hostile conservative State governments as well as cope with all the other difficulties.

No-one is suggesting that the supported accommodation assistance program will solve all the funding problems faced by women's refuges. Nevertheless, the proposals are a vast improvement on the old system. We will have security of funding, with a legislative base. There will be the flexibility for women's refuges to choose the sub-program which best suits their specific needs. There will be co-ordination and all supported accommodation for women, including child care in women's refuges. We will have the scope to cater for a broad range of women in crisis, whether they are chronically homeless or in a temporary crisis, and refuges will be able to focus more on services assisting women escaping violent or otherwise intolerable domestic situations. Funds have been provided this financial year for improving salaries and operating subsidies. More money has been promised for 1985-86 for new services and increased staffing.

For the first time we have guaranteed indexed increases in the salary component or grants to reflect the growth of wages. We have funds for program evaluation and a whole new approach to the development of a needs based system which recognises the importance of involving the service providers in planning for needs and priorities. A particularly significant point is that the new legislation will, for the first time, bring community based rape and incest crisis centres under the umbrella of Commonwealth assistance. The Bill and the complementary crisis accommodation program provide both for capital and recurrent funding, and the major component of recurrent costs-that is, an estimated 80 per cent of all SAAP funds-will be for salary subsidies to workers who provide support services such as counselling, information, referral and follow-up. Support services under the women's sub-program will extend to advice, assistance and advocacy in regard to legal problems, housing, health, child care and income support.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I want to end on a cautionary note. As workers in the field know, one of the major causes of women needing refuges is domestic violence-now recognised as a major problem with grave social implications-which in turn is all too often a factor in family proverty. The problems are not going to diminish quickly. The Australian Institute of Family Studies has just found that there were about 382,000 families, with three-quarters of a million children, living in poverty in 1982. I suggest that a number of those would be on supporting parents benefits and the thought of cutting them off is quite horrifying. There is no room for complacency over the new provisions under discussion here today, as I know the Minister would be the first to agree. The Bill represents an important first step, particularly in an administrative sense, but I would urge continuing vigilance on the part of the service providers, the funding administrators and all the Ministers concerned. With this legislation in place, Australia at last has the chance to develop a supported accommodation program which will provide effective and appropriate assistance to the homeless.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is a failing of the Hawke Labor Government it is that it does not remind the Australian people enough of the monstrous injustices and maladministration of the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government and its coalition predecessors. The wasted opportunities, the narrow, short-sighted, quick fix and the patronage of decaying social and economic structures are all well-established hallmarks of Liberal-National Party policy in government. If this country is suffering from unemployment, we must look at those who ran this country for 31 of the last 36 years, or nearly nine out of every ten years in that time. It is the ineptitude of these former conservative governments which allowed our factories to turn into industrial museums and which, with the ordinary taxpayers' money, through investment allowances and other ineptitudes, sent billions of dollars of work and industrial development to the United States of America, Germany, Britain and Japan. It was the former Ministers of these Liberal-National Party governments who now criticise this Government's short period of office, which is still spoken of in months and not years. It is the Liberal-National Party governments which have led this country into the economic quicksand. The billions of dollars of interest on overseas borrowings that the taxpayer must now bear are a direct result of the gross ineptitude of the Fraser Government and its Ministers, many of whom now sit on the Opposition front and back benches pretending to be economic saints and gurus.

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke Government, by any comparison, has achieved an economic recovery unparalleled in the Australian post-war experience. In a mere 22 months, 341,000 jobs have been created because of direct government involvement in programs such as the community employment program, through the success of the prices and income accord, through the consultation and consensus processes of the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the Business Council of Australia and the now mostly forgotten but underestimated success of the National Economic Summit Conference. It took the Fraser Government seven years to achieve the same thing while it was trying to fight inflation first. What a joke! While it was fighting inflation first by putting people out of work and raking up massive overseas borrowings for future generations to support, the inflation rate kept going up and up and the unemployment figures kept going up and up until they exceeded three-quarters of a million people, with many hundreds of thousands more in hidden unemployment. Even with such job growth and economic growth, industrial disputation, except in neo-fascist governed States such as Queensland, is at a record low in Australia today.

I will not go through all the economic comparisons now. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), during Question Time this week, has already magnificently exposed the glaring comparison by any standards between the success achieved by this Government and the failure of the former Liberal-National Party Government and its remnants sitting opposite. If one really stretched mercy one could begin to forgive those opposite for their gross ineptitude, but what they have done to the lives of millions of Australians today is quite unforgivable because it was done with their full knowledge while in government. Up to three million people in Australia now live in poverty. The life of one person in every five is restricted in opportunity, basic comfort, security, nutrition, health and justice. Every time the issue of poverty is raised by a member of the Government, those on the other side, in their arrogance, smirk. Those same people who so sanctimoniously took their Christian Bible in their hands for the swearing in ceremony in this House as a badge of their righteousness deny the first principles of Christianity-care for your fellow human beings, especially those who cannot protect themselves. Their golden rule is not 'Do unto others as you would have them do unto you'; the golden rule of the members of the Liberal and National parties is 'Whoever has the gold makes the rules'.

Poverty is the greatest blight and restriction upon this country. It affects us all, directly or indirectly, whether rich or poor. Before those opposite chortle 'Why doesn't the Government not do something', let us look at the extent of poverty as it grew under their patronage. In 1968 the top 10 per cent of income earners in Australia had 10 times the income of the bottom 10 per cent. By 1982, a mere 14 years later, for every $1,000 paid to the poor, the rich received $56,000. Apart from three years under the Whitlam Government, when there were significant steps to reduce poverty in this country, the onus for this regressive redistribution of wealth lies upon those opposite. They cannot get away from it. One has only to go back to the beginning of this week to see that they are not prepared even to admit their mistakes or to redress any of the injustices they have caused. Five times in two years and, as late as the beginning of this week, they have voted against the bottom of the harbour Bills which are designed, as they know only too well, to recoup the tax revenue kept from the people of Australia by those opposite because of their inability or unwillingness to crack down on tax avoidance and evasion. Honourable members opposite are always saying how concerned they are about the Australian family. The tax avoidance and evasion that they presided over costs the average Australian family about $43 a week, but the Opposition in this House does not care.

I return to the figures I mentioned earlier. In 1968 the top 10 per cent of income earners had 10 times the income of the bottom 10 per cent. By 1982, for every $1,000 paid to the poor, the rich received $56,000. To put it another way, the wealthiest 2,500 Australians now own as much of this country's wealth as the poorest two and a half million. Nearly 800,000 children are included amongst the poorest two and a half million people in this country. To gain an idea of the magnitude of the maldistribution of this common wealth of Australia that has occurred under those opposite, if those two and a half million poorest Australians stood hand in hand the line would stretch from Sydney to Perth. I ask honourable members to think about that. A line of people over 3,000 kilometres long would stretch all the way from Sydney to Perth. If the wealthiest 2,500 Australians, who own as much wealth as those two and a half million Australians at the bottom end of the income scale, stood hand in hand they would be lucky to reach a distance of three kilometres, the distance between a couple of average suburban railway stations. That is the extent of the maldistribution of wealth in this country. Those opposite, the protectors, the puppets of the greedy tax avoiders and evaders, have deliberately ignored the plight of those in poverty in Australia today.

In those three years there has been a monstrous increase in the number of both two-parent and single parent families living below the poverty line in Australia. In my electorate of Jagajaga, more than $190,000 was distributed in emergency relief last year. On average, each applicant received $30 on four occasions throughout the year. That means that nearly 2,000 families are living on the poor box poverty line. One cannot get much lower than that if one has to ask not just for a pension or a benefit, which one is entitled to, but for a handout from the poor box. Can honourable members imagine the degradation and the extent of the poverty that people in this situation have to face? It is deplorable and it is the duty of this House and of everybody else to ensure that the load is lifted from the poor of this country and shared more evenly.

SPEECH.PARA: Today thousands of Australian children will go to bed hungry. That is a fact. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) well knows the extent of poverty in his electorate and the problems that mothers have to go through. As he has told me at other times, women have had to sell themselves into prostitution to get food for their children. It is just not good enough. Because of the extremes of poverty many parents of young people will expose themselves to great risks in this country today, tomorrow and for years to come unless we do something. Poverty is a fact of life. Where the next meal will come from, where the next piece of clothing will come from, are problems that affect many people in Australia today.

It is our national responsibility to address poverty, its causes and effects, right now. It is not just the job of this Government, a job which is well under way; it is the job of the Opposition, both Houses of Parliament, and the community of Australia to recognise the needs that exist today of those millions of our fellow citizens in poverty.

In less than one thousand days we will celebrate the bicentenary of European settlement in this country. Leading up to our bicentennial year in 1988 is the International Year of the Homeless in 1987. I, for one, welcome the passage through this House of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Bill, after years of token pilot schemes for the homeless under Liberal-National Party governments. The Year of the Homeless in 1987 should remind us that if we do not effectively address ourselves to attaching the highest priority to the issue of poverty over the next thousand days, we will have little of real value to celebrate. Taxation reform is the obvious and most powerful vehicle to address this issue. As my good colleague the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), with his usual eloquence, pointed out only last night in this debate, the facts are clear. The pay-as-you-earn taxpayer has been copping it in the neck, and those on the lowest incomes are affected the most because of the limitations of their disposable incomes.

In various ways these Appropriation Bills address aspects of poverty, but today the duty is upon us all on both sides of this House, in the other place, in parliaments throughout Australia, in local councils, communities and families and as individual Australians to act now to stop the poverty that exists in this country, otherwise our bicentenary year will be a very hollow affair despite all the crackers, fireworks, television jingles, and so on.

Poverty should be a political issue in this country, an issue which governments can quite comfortably go to the electorate on and speak strongly on. Voters not in poverty should show concern for their friends and neighbours and those people they do not know who are in great poverty in this country. To assist in raising poverty as an election issue, a real political issue, in this House and in the community, I will be organising a poverty summit in my electorate, starting on 28 April, to look at different facets of poverty. The poverty summit will continue throughout the year. The first session, on Sunday, 28 April, will focus on poverty and tax reform. I invite all honourable and members of the community to attend that poverty summit, because true tax reform will do more to alleviate poverty in this country and to share the common wealth of Australia. People should think of the words 'Commonwealth of Australia' as meaning to share the common wealth of Australia more equitably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the fundamental duty of the government of any nation to protect its population and territorial integrity against armed aggression and occupation by an aggressor. That should be the prime obligation of any government, including the present Government. All the welfare programs that can be dreamt up are worthless and will become meaningless if this country is not in a position to defend its territory and defend all Australians. Territorial defence must also, of necessity, include our ability to keep open sea lanes and maintain an ability to trade and resupply.

SPEECH.PARA: Events over the past six months have brought into sharp focus the shortcomings of the present Government, along with the most serious consequences for any Australian Government, present or future, in its failure farsightedly to plan the future defence posture of this country. Minority interest factions within the Australian Labor Party have, deliberately or otherwise, managed to reduce contemporary debate on issues affecting the security of our region to narrow, and in many ways irrelevant, dimensions. Planning for defence against possible future threats has been consumed by the need to justify our traditional alliances rather than concentrating on the best and most affordable defence for Australia over the next 15 years and well into the next century. The plight of our defence forces has been adequately covered by my colleague the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and others on this side and I do not intend to dwell on our present state of unreadiness.

Of immediate concern to many is our alliance with the only great military power and hitherto reliable military ally to which we might turn in the event of a threat to our national integrity. That very great country is, of course, the United States of America. Our relationship with this politically stable friend and ally has deteriorated rapidly in recent times under this apology for a government. Integral to our approach to defence of this country should be an awareness of the fact that it takes an unprepared democracy a great deal of time to react to threats, real or perceived. It is therefore a delusion-a potentially disastrous delusion-to be as soft on defence as the present Government, or to rely on an absence of identifiable, real or perceived threats for the time being.

Most Australians must deplore the Government's weak-kneed reactionary stances to what under a coalition government would have been normal, everyday exchanges and co-operation with our United States ally. The MX missile testing crisis could have occurred only under this Government. The actions of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Government during that episode are well reported, and the fact that he had to be bailed out by the United States Administration, because of internal Labor Party faction fighting, brought no credit to him or his Government.

Strains on ANZUS, although initiated by the New Zealand Government, have reached, or possibly gone beyond, breaking point because of the ineptitude of this socialist Prime Minister and his Government. Australia's role in rail-gun research, where we have led the world, is under threat. Our participation in some of the research for the United States strategic defence initiative is not just under threat but has been abandoned to other nations in the free world, to our eternal shame. That abandonment is not the outcome of reasoned debate, but because one or more factions of the Labor Party would not have a bar of it.

Under the present Government, Australia has clearly signalled that it is unable to take its place alongside its allies in assuming responsibility for the future defence of our region, and has seriously cast doubt upon our resolve to be able to defend our own people. For the first time in decades, debate on defence is newsworthy, albeit for the wrong reasons. To the extent that the Government has been tested in this context in public forums, it has failed miserably.

Meanwhile, accepting the responsibility thrust on it by the Western alliance, the United States is maintaining major naval and military bases in Japan, the Philippines and Diego Garcia, which enable it to sustain a very considerable deterrence against aggression in our region, in particular the western Pacific and eastern Indian Ocean regions. Political instablity in the Philippines and the expiration of the lease for Subic Bay in 1991, just six years hence, have monumental implications for our region and our security. While there may be no identifiable threat in our region for the time being, it is not implausible to come to the conclusion that that state of affairs exists because of the deterrence provided by the substantial United States presence and our alliance with that country.

Planning for the 1990s and beyond must surely take into account the contingency that the United States will no longer be able to operate from Clark Base and Subic Bay in the Philippines. In that unthinkable event, the Soviet presence in Cam Ranh Bay will be of even more critical significance. It must be a serious possibility that United States facilities which will enable it to operate naval and air forces in the southern Pacific may have to contract to Guam and Hawaii. Given that possible scenario, and the fact that the nearest United States naval and air base is limited to Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean, outright defence of our shipping lanes and eastern and western seaboards will become even more the responsibility of Australia.

The great tragedy, for those of us who regard our defences as of both paramount importance and inseparable from a workable alliance with the United States, is this socialist Government's capitulation to those who vociferously advocate the removal of all joint Australia-United States facilities on our soil.

If that conclusion needs corroboration, we need look no further back than last weekend. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) made a virtue out of his Government's withdrawal of an offer by the coalition government to the United States to consider the use of naval facilities at Cockburn Sound in his own State of Western Australia. He did so in a particular context, of course; in a debate before school kids. Instead of showing leadership and farsightedness, he close the easy way and disqualified his Party and his Government from an option which could and should be explored before identifiable needs and threats arise.

Regional and national defence history has shown that it can be fatal to wait until one's head is on the block before making plans and canvassing all conceivable options. The Minister, his Government and his Party have lost their heads, all because of a possible lack of electoral popularity in the face of the loss of a Senate seat to the Nuclear Disarmament Party and a Palm Sunday rally or two around the country.

In employing the argument that the offer made by the coalition in government somehow detracts from a commitment to maximum self-reliance in defence, the Minister, of necessity, opens up to question the continued co-operation with the United States in joint facilities in this country. That may not have been the intention of the Minister in choosing the words he used last weekend, but it is at once the logical and undesirable consequences of those words. The Minister cannot have it both ways. He cannot say, on the one hand, that joint facilities of one kind may remain and, on the other, that other and new joint facilities cannot even be discussed as being desirable for all time to come. If he thinks that is consistent in logic, he has given the mad Left of his Party a whole new line of argument. If he does not and his gloating over the withdrawal of future access to the Stirling naval base facilities is a one-off decision, the Minister for Defence is guilty of mortgaging the future of this country's defences by denying even the planning involved in making a joint naval facility on our western seaboard a goer.

In a major conflict, regional defence will almost inevitably involve the United States, failing which, quite clearly, there will be no regional defence capable of meeting all future threats. In pandering to the Australian Labor Party's reactionaries who see evil in our enduring friendship with the United States, spanning 40 or more years, the Government is forgoing, or is on the brink on forgoing, any claim to the good will of the only democratic super-power of modern times. Above all, the Government is now in a position that prevents it from contingency planning for future United States military bases on Australian soil as may become essential for Australia's defence.

In the context of a debate on defence and our defence posture, it is necessary to comment on our economic performance as a country. A sound economy is an indispensable prerequisite to our ability to defend our populace against possible external aggression. With Australia's defence efforts and planning being inhibited by poor economic performance and prospects under this Government, it is necessary to comment on that performance and those prospects. Time and again it has been necessary to restate the lack of certainty created in the private sector by the Government's inability to state its clear and firm intentions in relation to economic matters and taxation. All too often, this uncertainty is due to ad hockery and on the run economic decision making. Under pressure the Prime Minister has shown a propensity to make pronouncements which have not been thought through for their impact on decision taking in the wealth creating private sector. It is well known that the Prime Minister decided to hold a tax summit in July of this year following what was at best a throwaway comment by an unqualified radio commentator in Perth during the last election campaign. That decision served a useful purpose in that it got the Prime Minister and his Government off the hook in the absence of an ALP policy on tax in the runup to that election. Since then, of course, the sky has been darkened by kites being flown by the Prime Minister, other Ministers and ALP factions galore. In the eclipse-like gloom that exists as a result of the Prime Minister's tax summit folly, private decision takers are groping in the dark for want of certainty as to the direction of the Government on taxation policy.

Let us look at some of the promised events in the next few months which are bound to exacerbate the profound uncertainty with which the wealth creating sector will have to grapple. As I have already mentioned, there is the tax summit. There is the prospect of another wage indexation hearing later in the year. There are likely to be across the board wage increases for increased productivity. There will almost certainly be an extension of employment deflating redundancy extravagance into even more and more awards. We are likely to be confronted with occupational safety imposts which are likely to break new and unexplored ground. We are almost certain to cop an extension of obligatory non-contributory superannuation funds at the prompting of and with the connivance of the Hawke Government, which will cost employers an additional $11 a week per employee. We certainly will have to face up to renegotiation of wage fixing guidelines between the Government and-guess who?-its masters in the Australian Council of Trade Unions and all that that may mean. We will be confronted by new wage relativity claims of the type mentioned in the grievance debate yesterday. Then there will be observance of the aptly named trilogy. I say it is aptly named because the Concise Oxford Dictionary tells us that a trilogy is 'a set of three tragedies to be performed in immediate succession'. The Prime Minister's trilogy is surely about tragedies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister been made aware of plans for further industrial action by the Australian Council of Trade Unions or individual unions following today's boycott? What steps has he taken to dissuade those involved from engaging in further industrial action? Will he tell the Australian people what those future industrial actions are so that they can make plans to protect themselves from the disruption of their activities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, of course, aware, as the public is, of the intention for a continued campaign after today's blockade, but I have no detailed awareness of what that will involve. I am not even sure that there is any clear plan by the trade unions in that respect.
—Why don't you contact them?

—They may not tell me. The reality, of course, is that, if the Leader of the Opposition wants to know those plans, he might phone the Australian Council of Trade Unions himself. He cannot expect me to know everything that is in the mind of the ACTU. It is a matter of concern to us that the industrial action is occurring today and that there is an intention for further industrial action to take place if there are no consultations by the Queensland Government. We have made clear our opposition to that course of events. We have done everything that we can to try to put events on a more conciliatory course and to bring about a situation in which such industrial confrontation will not occur.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, the resolution of this matter remains in the hands of the Queensland Government. It could stop the whole thing by consultations. It behoves the Queensland Government to start acting responsibly and to discuss these matters with the unions, because any industrial dispute must, in the end, be ended by some form of negotiations between the parties. Whilst the stand off attitude of the Queensland Government continues, I am afraid that there is nothing that the Federal Government can do to prevent further deterioration in the industrial situation.

The Government very much welcomes the return to work in a number of New South Wales hospitals. ANSWER.PARA: This Government appreciates the strong stand taken by the President of the Australian Medical Association in working to make this peace package effective. We also welcome the fact that nearly every major health care organisation in New South Wales has endorsed the peace proposals. Again, we are grateful that the Leader of the Liberal Opposition in New South Wales also urged the doctors to return to work under this package. Indeed, the only allies that the militant surgeons now have are those honourable members who sit on the Federal Opposition back benches. Those surgeons and the Federal Opposition deserve each other.

When I was in Melbourne last Friday morning, I heard the dulcet tones of the Leader of the Opposition when he was speaking on a discussion program with Derryn Hinch. I thought that he was disagreeing with the honourable member for Barker and some of the hard-line people on the Federal Opposition benches, because this is what I heard him saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong again. What about the 20,000 in queues in Melbourne waiting for hospital beds? What are you doing about them?
—Honourable members opposite certainly do not like these statements. This is what the Leader of the Opposition said:

ANSWER.PARA: You'll remember the hurt at the time, you'll remember the old people, and the young, who suffered because these people were not prepared to allow some private contractual work to be done-and they withdrew their services.

I thought that he was talking about the surgeons-because this is what the surgeons have done. They have hurt old people. They have hurt the young. These people have suffered because of the withdrawal of their services. But of course, when I listened on, I realised that he was not talking about surgeons, who, at a minimum, earn $1,000 a week; he was talking about ordinary workers. They cannot withdraw essential services; they cannot harm the sick. But the surgeons are excluded. Opposition members clearly have double standards. In relation to the surgeons, they are prepared to support them; whatever the compromises offered, whatever the negotiations offered, whatever outrageous demand the surgeons make, they are prepared to back them. But for ordinary working men, they are not prepared to support negotiations or to support compromise; they are prepared simply to back those who put the boot in. That is a clear example of double standards. In this House we do not have a responsible Opposition; we have an organised hypocrisy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations to his answer to my question yesterday, when he said that he had consulted with some of the companies on the Australian Council of Trade Unions hit list. Did the Minister offer the companies government assistance against the ACTU industrial campaign? If so, what assistance did he offer? If not, why not?

—In discussions that I had with the people involved, I simply said the kind of things that I have said in this House in terms of what the Government's attitudes were. I was not asked in any way to do anything more than we had already done.
—Is the Minister for Social Security aware of claims about the effects of the assets test?
—He is deaf, dumb and blind if he isn't.
—Whilst there has been discussion in this House about those affected, will he tell the House whether any millionaires have been caught by the assets test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the right honourable member for New England saying that he would be surprised if I were not aware of this. I have been somewhat surprised, given the bleating that occurs in this House, at the relatively small number of representations that I have received from individual honourable members on particular cases of hardship. That is indicative of a great deal of misrepresentation and falsification, both inside and outside the House, about the assets test. Indeed, I suppose that if we have learnt any lessons from the assets test, one is that it has shown the very large number of people with significant wealth who have been paid social security benefits in this country.
—How many?

—The figures show that at least 12 millionaires had their pensions cancelled as a result of the assets test-12 millionaires being funded out of the public purse, 12 people receiving income from the Government that might have been paid to the needy people of this country. The Opposition talks about needy people and the need to direct income to those most in need. If the members of the Opposition want some facts, I will give them some. There are 12 millionaires who are dependent on the public purse and who are receiving income security. Twelve millionaires are competing with the poorest people in this community for an additional dollar on their pension. As the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) was pointing out, this exercise, along with that affecting the surgeons in New South Wales, indicates who the real interests are that the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia are serving. Essentially they are the wealthy and the most privileged people in the community. Members of the Opposition can bleat and go on, but so much of it is crocodile tears and hypocrisy.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me illustrate the wealth the assets test has uncovered, the wealth the Opposition wants to protect. Two-thirds of the people who had their pensions cancelled did not even bother to complete the details on the form. They recognised that their wealth would not entitle them to receive a pension and they self-cancelled. Most of those who provided details and whose pensions were cancelled had assets in investments, some of them contrived to deliver an artificially low yield. I have referred to that before and I will go on to it again later this afternoon. More than half of them had assets returning a yield of 5 per cent or less. So we are talking about people with very substantial assets who are involved in minimising the income associated with those assets.

The assets test has certainly cut off a number of people in the community from receiving a pension but it has saved $100m, which this Government will direct to the people who are most in need. Our priorities are clear. We know whom it is we are here to serve in this country. Let me say something about people who are on pensions because I do not think the Opposition is all that strong when it gets down to looking at the details. Something like 1.5 million pensioners in this country are receiving the full pension. Those 1.5 million are subject to an extraordinarily strict income test. If anyone thinks that income testing in this country is not strict, let me illustrate that it is. Those people receive a full pension because they have an income less than $30 a week. Members of the Opposition want to defend the rights of millionaires in this country to receive a $50 pension and invest their money in a way that will contribute nothing towards the well-being of this community and the production of wealth in this country. Very often they will put money into the hands of accountants and people who will benefit without contributing a jot to the wealth of the community as a whole.

I refer him to his Press release of 16 April and his answer in this House yesterday to the Leader of the Opposition that talks he is proposing with this Government, the Queensland Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions would address the central issue of the re-employment of 900 linesmen of the Electrical Trades Union of Australia in the Queensland power dispute. Is the Minister aware that all positions have been filled and therefore no vacancies exist with the employing authority, the South East Queensland Electricity Board? Does the Minister propose that the men now employed-including 600 continuing SEQEB employees, more than 200 who were previously employed by the authority and 100 new employees who were previously unemployed-be sacked? If not, how and where does he propose that the former employees be employed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that the reinstatement of the employees is the most important issue in the settlement of this dispute and the prevention of further industrial action. That is a very important matter and one which I believe the Queensland Government should be addressing now. I do not accept the honourable member's basic premise that those jobs have all been filled. I understand it is the case that there is reliance on private contractors to a substantial degree. Those people are not full employees, they are private contractors working on a contractual basis. Of the original 1500, I understand that several hundred were never out of work in the first place, either because they did not go off the job, they were away on leave, or whatever. Of those who did go off, over 100 or so have come back-I think that was the figure used by the honourable member. The rest have not come back. Of course these are very important negotiations involving, as they do, something like 11 million tonnes of steaming coal to Japan. Because the negotiations are at a delicate stage I do not intend to go into the substance of the matters which were covered by the report. However, I inform the House that the export controls I am administering are those which were introduced by Doug Anthony when he was Minister for Trade and Resources and decided to strengthen the controls previously put in place by the late Rex Connor. Doug Anthony did not think that Rex Connor's export controls were good enough or strong enough. Under the operation of those export controls the coking coal negotiations with Japan have been satisfactorily finalised. In relation to steaming coal, it has to be remembered that those contracts are written in Australian dollars whereas coal from our international competitors is expressed in United States dollars.

ANSWER.PARA: What I will be doing in the administration of Doug Anthony's export controls is ensuring that we maximise the benefits for Australia as a whole. The arrangements which we have in place do ensure the closest possible consultation with the industry, particularly in regard to the way in which we arrive at the kind of price that ought to be aimed for during these negotiations. Of course it is not always possible to get a unanimous view out of the industry and there may sometimes be a temptation on the part of some companies within the industry to trail their coats publicly when they disagree with any decision that might be taken. Unfortunately it appears to be the case on this occasion that that temptation was not resisted, and one has to say that the appearance of this article could only have given comfort to our buyers. The commercial interests of coal companies are their own business but the national interest in these matters is my business, and I assure the House that I will always put the national interest first. I have nothing but contempt for those people who want to pursue their own private interests at the expense of the national interest.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. I ask the Attorney whether he has seen this statement today by Mr Temby, the Director of Public Prosecutions:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not ask the Director of Public Prosecutions to resign. He is entitled to express any views he wishes, which he did, as I note, when addressing graduates I think at Perth university or something of that nature.
—He disagrees with the Government's policy though.
—I think the Leader of the Opposition would agree that in a free society if he expresses a view about a government policy--
—He is the Director of Public Prosecutions.
—Let me come to the point. Mr Speaker, we always have a series of interjections which in turn create another lot of questions.
—I invite the Deputy Prime Minister not to respond to any of those questions.

—I was hoping you would say that, Mr Speaker. It is important to look at the drug summit and the fact that the Costigan Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union gave a view on what might be termed powers that ought to be given to law enforcement agencies. If we want to consider the other point of view, we must look at the balance of the public interest as against the rights of privacy. That is the big challenge in any society, particularly when we are dealing with a criminal element. It affects the questions of indemnities, of mail interception and of telephone interception. We have laws which prohibit that, naturally, but in the course of pursuing criminals we have to get a balance. Do we give law enforcement officers, under appropriate supervision-such as judicial warrants-the right to try to ascertain whether there are criminal activities that could be pursued? So in a society a balance has to be struck. Mr Temby has never disagreed with that. He is obviously disagreeing to some extent with Mr Costigan's recommendations. At the drug summit, as the honourable member may or may not know, it was indicated to the Premiers that they might wish to seek access to telephone interception under appropriate judicial warrants, because let us recognise that the problem of narcotics, in particular, is not solely the preserve of the Australian Federal Police. It is obvious, if we look at the State administration of law enforcement, that a lot of criminal activity relating to narcotics comes under State jurisdiction. So we can get a balance-I think a reasonable balance-between what Mr Costigan was about in regard to whether State governments might ask for that power. It was indicated that if they did ask the Government would consider the matter favourably. Let us make that clear. It is a question of what State Premiers want to ask for. This matter was left with them and I have no doubt that representations will be made. I think, if I assess it correctly, that the public opinion would be on the side of the Government if it said that, where the question of balance relates to the pursuit of criminals, particularly in the narcotics area, it would favour pursuing criminals as against opting for the right of privacy. Of course it has to have the balance brought about by the need for judicial warrant.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the further point that Mr Temby, in the course of his appointment as Director of Public Prosecutions, has to have evidence which would warrant a prosecution. I have no doubt that if evidence were given to Mr Temby he would be able to pursue the prosecution. His opinion as to whether the evidence should be obtained one way or another is a personal one. The fact that the evidence is available obliges him to carry out his duties.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMY: SIGNIFICANCE OF VISIT BY MR HU YAOBANG

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. What is the significance for Australia and the Australian economy of the recent visit of the Chinese official, Mr Hu Yaobang?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lowe for his question without notice. He never misses; he is consistent. Unfortunately, only 15 minutes of Question Time remain, which does not allow me to do justice to the very significant possibilities that have been opened up for Australia. I will content myself, very briefly, with making some observations. The first is based upon the fact that I still think it is the case that not enough people in this country and in other parts of the world appreciate the significance of what is occurring in China at present. As I have said, we are witnessing a quiet revolution in China, whereby the enormous initiative and enterprise of hundreds of millions of Chinese people are being released in a way in which they have not been in the last 40 years. Associated with that change in their economic approach to production and distribution, they are also opening their country to the West.

ANSWER.PARA: It is extremely fortunate that, because of the initiative that was taken by Mr Whitlam and maintained, to his credit, under the Prime Ministership of Malcolm Fraser, we have been able, in recognising these changes that have taken place in China in recent years, to take advantage of the special relationship that I think is developing between Australia and China.

There are so many areas in which this relationship has now been manifested that I cannot exhaustively deal with them all. Let me deal with some of the more obviously important ones. There is the iron and steel initiative, which itself is manifested in a number of ways. It is manifested in the increase in the exports of iron ore and semi-finished products to China, which increased by 53 per cent last year. There will be joint ventures in Australia and in China between enterprises of the two countries in the iron and steel industry. There will be the transfer of the very considerable advances in Australian technology in this field. There is also the significant increase in the export of manganese from Australia to China. I imagine that, within this year, we will see the finalisation of some very significant developments in Australia to which reference has already been made. In a period of some 14 or 15 months, those developments have been quite remarkable. It is a matter of great importance for Australia, an importance which will be understood and appreciated by my friends in one corner of the chamber-

TALK.START.PARA: —Cockies' corner.

—It is referred to irreverently as cockies' corner. However it is described, I know it is appreciated because I had the opportunity of introducing some of those gentlemen to Hu Yaobang and I was appreciative of the opportunity of doing that. We are now replicating in the wool industry the concept and the approach that have been so successful in the iron and steel industry. That will be of great importance for Australia because we will now have extensive co-operation at all levels of the wool industry, from the export of raw wool and semi-finished products to our technology going to China to help it with the development of its textile industry and the development of its flocks. So we will have an enormous, extensive and comprehensive degree of co-operation between the two countries in the wool industry. I believe that we will also be able to do a great deal in the non-ferrous metal areas and, if I may so, in the agricultural industry generally. We have confirmed the extensive degree of co-operation that will take place in the areas of research and the application to China of so much of the development in agricultural and applied research that is occurring within Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that one of the very significant areas of importance for China and, in a flow on sense, for Australia will be the acceptance by Mr Hu Yaobang of our offer to send an expert team to China to look at its transport needs. Sir Peter Abeles will head that team. I believe that there will be an opportunity to take to China the experience of Australia in transport economics, which is so important. We have had experience in the areas of rail, road, shipping and aviation in a very large country. I believe that we will be able to be of considerable assistance to China and there will be a very valuable spin-off for Australia.

Having said all those things in the economic sphere, I want to tie it together, in conclusion, and say that what is tremendously important is the fact that we see emerging the capacity of two very important countries in the region of different social systems and different backgrounds to be able to work together constructively not only in the economic field but also in the cultural field. Ultimately, the great benefit of this will be not so much just in the economic field but I believe it will make a great contribution to the cause of regional peace and stability.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of widespread interest and concern, can the Prime Minister clarify whether or not the Government intends to advocate before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the discounting of wage increases for inflation caused by currency fluctuations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the Treasurer and I have addressed ourselves to this matter at length. I content myself with saying these things: Firstly, it should be understood that the first case that will be coming before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will be in approximately September which will cover the March and June quarters. There will be no impact of the devaluation in the March quarter figures. So all that will be before the Commission will be the figures in respect of the June quarter. It is the expectation that that will be a very low element in any move in the consumer price index figures for the combination of March and June. Nevertheless, the Government will be looking at these figures and will be formulating the position that we should put before the Commission at that time. What should be really understood is that it is 12 months away. It will be April of next year before this matter will be before the Commission in any possibly substantive way involving a reflection of the devaluation effect in the consumer price index.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said-I give the Australian community the reassurance that the Treasurer and I have given-this Government will not allow the very substantial benefits that will flow to the Australian economy from the current devaluation to be dissipated by an inflationary spiral. With respect to the wages area, that matter will not be substantially before the Commission for almost 12 months. While those on the other side, on their past record, have given no evidence of their capacity in economic management, I will just give them this lesson: It is an exercise in futility to make a decision about a situation, the elements of which one does not know, 12 months in advance. All the people of Australia need to know, and they will accept our assurance, is that when the time comes the appropriate decisions will be taken which will ensure that those benefits of devaluation will be maintained for the whole of the Australian people.
