DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE COMMITTEE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 9 October, the Parliamentary Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee tabled its report entitled 'Australia and ASEAN-Challenges and Opportunities'. It is my task today, on behalf of the Government, to respond to that report. Allow me first, however, to pay a tribute to the former Chairman of the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, Bill Morrison, who presented the report to the House and whose personal stamp is, I believe, very clearly on it. As honourable members will know, Bill Morrison will shortly be in a position, as Ambassador to Indonesia, to contribute further to the development of Australia's interests in the region. The Government looks forward to a continuation of his vigorous and constructive advice on the development of Australia's interests.

SPEECH.PARA: The report is a most welcome review of developments in the Association of South East Asian Nations region of interest to Australia, of Australia's policies towards the region and of our future prospects there. It is constructive in tone and makes a number of thoughtful and helpful suggestions about how our relations may be developed further. I should like to address briefly the report's major themes. I shall then seek leave to have a schedule of responses to the Committee's individual recommendations incorporated in Hansard.

The Government fully shares the Committee's view that 'no other part of the world promises to be of more consistent importance to Australia than the region of East and South East Asia, and that the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations form a significant part of this most economically dynamic region'. The Government's policies have been consistently developed upon that recognition. The development of our relations with the countries of ASEAN will continue to be given very high priority under this Government.

The Committee has identified quite comprehensively the range of national interest-political, defence and strategic, economic, immigration and cultural-that Australia has in its near region, in particular in ASEAN. These matters constitute an intricate web of interlocking interests and concerns that link Australia and ASEAN. These elements are usually best not dealt with in isolation, as a change in one element can significantly affect other parts of the whole but, for ease of presentation today, I should like to single out a number of strands which will serve to outline our policies to this point, and our future intentions.

It is well known that this Government has given very high priority to security matters in the region, most notably in seeking to contribute to a settlement in Cambodia. Much has been said lately against the Government's efforts in this direction. We have never said it would be easy or quick. But it is undeniable that a negotiated settlement, while still sadly a possibility rather than an imminent reality, would be the single greatest contribution to the stability of a region of prime strategic importance to Australia. As I have said before, the longer the Cambodian conflict continues, the more likely it is that there will come about that which we fear most-the intrusions of great power tensions into our immediate region through the increasing presence of external military forces and the exercise of force through proxies. Cambodia remains the greatest source of unresolved tension and instability in our region. The Australian Government therefore has a responsibility to continue to pursue the means by which a just solution might be found and the daily suffering of the Cambodian people brought to an end.

The Committee has quite cogently pointed out that we are in general agreement with the ASEAN states over Cambodia. ASEAN, like Australia, has always condemned the violation of Cambodia's sovereignty and called for the withdrawal of Vietnamese forces. We share a concern at the dangers of regional instability and heightened great power competition and tensions caused by the conflict in Cambodia. We also share a common concern at the burdens on the Cambodian people and their neighbours consequent upon the movement of refugees and displaced persons from and within Indo-China. Indeed, our concern as a major donor and country of asylum is direct and beyond dispute.

Beyond these shared concerns, the Committee notes that Australia has striven to make clear other implications of the situation which we would be unwise to ignore. In particular, we are concerned that the Khmer Rouge, led by Pol Pot, remains the largest and most effective component of the resistance coalition. We believe that to champion Pol Pot, however indirectly, is to place, not remove, obstacles to a just settlement. We have consistently warned of the dangers inherent in the present situation of recurring violence, which results in a continuation of suffering in Cambodia. It increases prospects of a widening conflict; it encourages tendencies towards a regional arms race; and it exacerbates the long term problems arising from Vietnam's international isolation and dependence on the Soviet Union.

The Committee observes that our regional policies have not been fully understood by ASEAN and that consultation is of prime importance. I would observe, in turn, that it is true that our policies on Cambodia have on occasion been misunderstood or perhaps misconstrued, but I would suggest that our clear and consistent enunciation of our concerns and the rationale behind them since 1983 have greatly improved the acceptance of our approach with ASEAN. Our role has been modest but it has been persistent. The single thread which unites all our efforts over the past two years has been the call for dialogue and compromise. It is to this end that I have spoken to leaders on all sides and at all distances from Cambodia. The Committee has made balanced and comprehensive judgments on the regional issues facing Australia, and I undertake that the Government will continue its efforts to search for a just Cambodian settlement and the development of Australia's relations with Vietnam in the cautious terms supported in the report. It is not in our own interests or those of our region for us to place barriers between ourselves and the countries of Indo-China.

As I mentioned earlier, the Government fully recognises the importance of close consultation with the ASEAN countries. I have taken many opportunities to consult with ASEAN leaders. I greatly value their views and will continue to seek them. I am sensitive to the vital importance of the situation in Cambodia to them and most especially to Thailand. There have been a number of points during our efforts on Cambodia at which we have reassured Thailand of our continuing friendship and our commitment to its security and well-being. I shall continue to provide these assurances unhesitatingly. I look forward to discussions with all of my ASEAN colleagues during the post ministerial conference to be held this year in Kuala Lumpur. I have no doubt that the matter of Cambodia will again be high on the agenda.

The Government is very much aware of the profound economic changes identified by the Committee that are taking place in the ASEAN region. While the ASEAN countries continue to face major economic challenges resulting from factors such as population size and growth rate and the associated crises of employment and poverty, and also structural weaknesses which make them vulnerable to trends in the international market, the weight of evidence suggests that most of the ASEAN economies have performed well so far and promise to perform well in the years ahead. These changes in the ASEAN region have important implications for us and the future economic health of Australia. The key question is that of our economic relevance to the ASEAN countries and indeed, the broader region.

I have previously drawn attention to the fact that the years ahead will call for flexibility and innovation on the part of Australian business and labour, matched by vision and determination on the part of government. The rest of the world does not owe us a living, nor particularly do the countries of the region, including the ASEAN states, few of whom have been endowed with the bounty of natural resources comparable to those we have in Australia. It is up to Australians, individually and collectively-politicians, business and employees-to provide the initiative and skills which will enable us to seize the economic opportunities in our region and, in so doing, contribute to and benefit from growth in the region. The bottom line for Australia is that, while the ASEAN countries will probably continue to offer expanding economic opportunities for non-ASEAN countries, we have no mortgage on these opportunities and will have to work hard to take advantage of them. If Australia is seriously intent on demonstrating its regional credentials it should have, or be able to develop, advantages of proximity and familiarity. It will be vitally important for the future of Australia that there is growing awareness of and discussion within the broader community of Australia's future economic directions. The Government will do what it can to facilitate this process. Indeed, the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is a very worthy contribution to this. But we also look to the universities, the media, and the business and union groupings to contribute to this process.

The Committee commented on discussions held on concepts of economic co-operation in the Pacific region. The Government's interest in promoting discussion of the economic changes in our region and exploring the processes of Pacific economic co-operation was reflected in our decision in mid-1984 to establish a National Pacific Co-operation Committee. The main activities of this Committee are to examine Australia's interests in possible paths towards economic co-operation with its neighbours in Asia and the Pacific and to co-ordinate future Australian participation in the Pacific economic co-operation process. Its membership is drawn from a cross-section of the Australian community and includes senior representatives of business, the unions, academic and the Public Service. As I noted last year, the Committee is a concrete expression of the Government's determination to stimulate community awareness of the economic importance to Australia of the Asia-Pacific region. We have continually emphasised the need for Australia to come to terms with and be involved in the possibilities and challenges offered by the fastest-growing region in the world. Australia has initiated consultations with regional countries, including the ASEAN countries, to encourage co-operative and mutually supportive approaches to multilateral trade problems. Progress has been pleasing and a frank and open exchange on issues of concern has developed.

Another major theme of the report is that of the distinctive identity of Australians in this region of the world, and the related necessity for developing human contacts between Australians and citizens of the ASEAN countries. I agree with the Committee that co-operation with ASEAN should be based on the recognition that 'Australia's political culture and processes are substantially different from those of the ASEAN states and that these differences are unlikely to diminish'. These differences are real but they do not diminish nor disguise our responsibilities and place in the region. It is our home. We cannot ignore the implications of our geographical position, nor the desire of our people to live in a region of harmony and rewarding international relationships. We are directly affected if the rivalry of great powers threatens peace in our region. We are directly concerned if our friends and neighbours are destabilised because of continuing tensions. We also bear many of the direct consequences of tensions and conflict in the region. Our long-standing and close association with ASEAN and the host of common interests which we share with our ASEAN neighbours compel us to work at further development of mutual awareness and understanding at all levels.

The promotion of mutual awareness and common interests is an area in which the Government's record is very strong. Australia's successful and extensive immigration and refugee programs have helped foster an interchange on the most personal level between Australia and ASEAN. The migrants who come from ASEAN countries make a significant contribution to Australia's increasingly cosmopolitan society. The Government has stressed the importance of people-to-people contacts between Australia and ASEAN. To that end, this Government has broadened the range of sponsored visitor and exchange schemes through which social, technical, and cultural exchanges are fostered. Another important aspect of the Government's policies to promote mutual awareness is Australia's commitment to Asian studies. Australia already ranks among the best centres for Asian studies in the world, particularly with regard to Indonesia. There is, however, always room for improvement and I am pleased, therefore, that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) and I have agreed to the establishment of a working party to examine the concept of the formation of an Asian studies council, as recommended by the Committee. The Government's private overseas student policy also plays a major role, reflected in the high proportion of students from ASEAN countries. As well as serving the development needs of their own countries, overseas students also take home with them an intimate understanding of Australia which helps to improve knowledge of Australia in the ASEAN countries. This Government is convinced of the value of fostering mutual awareness and common interests with the people of the ASEAN countries, and our record is testimony to our dedication in this respect. That dedication will not diminish under this Government.

In conclusion, I again thank the Committee for its detailed and thoughtful contribution on the subject of ASEAN-Australia relations. As will be evident from the schedule which I now seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard, a good deal of detailed consideration has already been given to the Committee's recommendations and much more is to follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —In all the Government's considerations there is the common judgment that Australia's future is inevitably intertwined with the future of the ASEAN region. Australia must make the most of the challenges and opportunities so well identified in this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) said, the Association of South East Asian Nations area is of immense importance to Australia and ASEAN is an association of nations who are our neighbours. Therefore, relations of Australia with the ASEAN countries are of the most vital and enduring significance. I made a statement on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence when our former colleague on the Committee, Mr Morrison, tabled it in the House some time ago. I join the Minister in wishing Mr Morrison all the very best of success in his new appointment. In my remarks today I will address the tabling statement of the Minister and aspects of his observations in the attached statement of Government responses which has just been tabled. The Committee, in its findings, endeavoured to criticise the assumption that we should distance Australia from ASEAN in favour of Vietnam. A very real and understandable view was growing up in the community that this Government and this Minister seemed to place much more emphasis on good relationships with Vietnam than on good relationships with ASEAN countries. As I have said, the Committee, in its findings, endeavoured to criticise that assumption.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to recall that ASEAN diplomacy had convinced the Third World, which voted 100 plus in favour of the ASEAN position at the United Nations, that peace and neutrality could be restored only by an internationally supervised settlement in Cambodia, not a settlement imposed by the continuing application of Vietnamese force-150,000 Vietnamese troops still occupy Cambodia-and not a settlement induced by Pol Pot, whose Cambodian forces still hold out and who, quite rightly, the Minister and the Government criticised. I just add parenthetically, that it was a Labor Government which initially recognised Pol Pot when he first came to power and boasted about it at the time.

ASEAN saw the need for a third force, a force based on giving a priority not to military effort but to political effort, a force which could creditably speak for the Cambodian people. ASEAN supported Prince Sihanouk and Son Sann and succeeded in getting agreement to the seating at the United Nations of Sihanouk instead of Pol Pot and instead of the puppet Government in Phnom Penh. This achievement was considerable and it has not been given sufficient credit by this Government or the Minister. It was at that stage that the Foreign Minister entered the scene and proceeded to muddy the international waters by taking a public line designed to reflect discredibility on ASEAN and more credibility on Vietnam. We all know the history of the overtures to Hanoi, the warnings to ASEAN, the embracing of Hanoi, the questioning concern of ASEAN. It got so bad that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had to step in and patch up the quarrel. It was against this background that the Joint Committee made its observations.

Basically, Australia can contribute but ASEAN carries the main burden. Its members, particularly Thailand, are in the front line. A public diplomacy which has the effect, although unintended, of undermining ASEAN and its sponsorship of the struggle for a free and independent Cambodia should be avoided, but this happened in a number of ways. We exaggerated differences between ASEAN members in their approach to the problem. Government spokesmen drew distinctions between Indonesia and Singapore, and between Thailand and Indonesia, and implies that those differences reflected support for our diplomacy and criticism. Government spokesmen equated differences between the Hawke Government and ASEAN with differences between the Fraser Government and ASEAN over civil aviation and protection. Last year, speaking on this aspect, I said:

It is inevitable that there will be divergent viewpoints emanating from Australia and ASEAN on economic issues in particular. We are not saying, nor is the Government Committee, nor is ASEAN, that differences are a sign of frailty. They may be a sign of strength. Clearly, just as there is a hierarchy of sensitivities, there is a corresponding hierarchy of permissible differences. The Fraser Government became involved in a strong dialogue on economic issues and civil aviation. Paragraph 3 of the foreword of the Committee's Report states:
. . . Australia must be perceptive in identifying and distinguishing policies which appear to be shared by ASEAN as a group and those in which there is a divergence among ASEAN members' opinion.

Some issues, for example ASEAN opposition to Australia's international civil aviation policy in the late 1970s and its approach to the problems of Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia, are presented in terms of ASEAN solidarity. It is true that ASEAN solidarity was a factor in the ASEAN approach to Australia on both these issues.

But it is a mistake to assume that solidarity on an economic issue is of the same order of sensitivity as solidarity on an issue affecting the fundamental security of the region. A moment's reflection will, I think, produce agreement on that point. The fact is that there will be times when our perceptions differ.

I hope that these lessons have been learnt, particularly having regard to the embarrassment caused by the Foreign Minister's last visit to ASEAN and to the Indo-Chinese areas of the world. That visit was, in all aspects, an almost unmitigated disaster. It was a total embarrassment for the Government because the Government's Foreign Minister had been shown as inept or naive or both. More than that, it was an embarrassment for Australia as a whole. The whole Australian nation had to bear the same embarrassment that the Government had to bear, and that was tragic.

I welcome the statement that the Government has reassured Thailand in particular of our continuing friendship and commitment to its security and well-being. The statement carries its own admission of the Government's management of its diplomacy, but the sincerity of that statement is all the more obvious for that reason. It is also obvious for another and more pragmatic reason-the Australian people would have it no other way and it is that reality which clothes the words and it is that reality which I trust the people and the Government of Thailand will take into full account.

It would indeed be remiss to continue a line of comment on the Kampuchean issue as if that tells the story of Australian-ASEAN relationships. Anyone interested may refer to Hansard of 9 October 1984, when I gave a more developed analysis. But the issue is an important one and claims prominence on that account. Supremely, our relationship with the members of ASEAN and the people of ASEAN is above the run of any particular issue. The loyalty to the bonds on both sides is so historically well founded and so historically strong that not even grave misunderstandings have the capacity to dissipate before the strength of our history.

We should not forget that it was a Labor Government which first ran up the flag of support for the independence of Indonesia. We should not forget that it was the coalition's decision to defend the peoples of Malaysia and Singapore against communist insurgency and the mistaken Sukarnoist policy of confrontation which contributed to the independent strength of Malaysia and Singapore in their period of emergence from colonial constitutions.

I think it is appropriate in this context to affirm our support for Australia's defence co-operation program. We on this side of the House will be watchful of particular developments to ensure that the gallery of detractors from the left wing of the Government are not successful in their efforts to reduce the effectiveness of the principle.

The Minister welcomes the Committee's recommendation on migration, and in doing so fails to acknowledge the part played by the Government in contributing to the unwelcome development of last year's controversy. The contribution was one distinctively made by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It was the statesmanlike utterances of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and, amongst others, the Minister for Foreign Affairs which did much to recover what for many might have appeared to be lost ground. It might be suggested that the interpolation of this comment in the Minister's statement today may be deemed unwise as it was unnecessary.

A significant contribution to refugees was made by Australia to a people fleeing the brutality of Vietnam. That must never be forgotten. Hundreds of thousands of people fled the brutality of the new regime in Indo-China. That action by Australia remains one of great social achievement and I hope that in the future the Government will administer the issue with practical wisdom and sensitivity.

Tourism is a significant force for mutual economic development and people to people contact. We welcome the recommendations on shipping services, and the Government's thinking in this is to be kept under study and review. We think that is a sensible reaction.
I wrap up my remarks by referring to two points, the first of which relates to human rights. I draw the attention of the House to the well-rounded comment by the Minister:

The Government believes however that it is essential to act constructively on human rights matters and most of Australia's human rights concerns can be most effectively pursued in the context of mutual understanding and sound bi-lateral relations . . .

The Government does not believe that aid should automatically be withheld from countries whose human rights record is poor. The adoption of such measures is most likely to inflict punishment on the poorest and most exposed who would be innocent of the human rights abuses perpetrated by their governments. There is a certain firmness in this position and an important sense of fairness too. We support it.

The second point I make relates to the role of Radio Australia, which is a major one. It has, under its current Director, made efforts to further define its role. There is an important service to the region in maintaining a lively insight into Australia's developments and a fair-minded view of regional developments. They have to be dealt with with a great deal of sensitivity and a great deal of understanding of differing viewpoints as seen from different parts of the globe.

In relation to education, let us all keep in mind that a great deal of benefit accrues to us in our capacity as a major resource in education. We should keep that aspect under enlightened review. The Committee's report was important and it was sound and fairly based. It made some strong recommendations which would be of help to governments of any political persuasion. I am glad that the Minister and the Government have responded to the report so promptly. Those responses to the recommendations are important and will continue to have a major impact on our continued attitude towards members of ASEAN and they will have a significant impact upon what is, after all, one of the most vital areas of significance to this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to comment on the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, entitled 'Australia and ASEAN-Challenges and Opportunities'. I shall limit my remarks to the response of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and the Government to the recommendation on conflicts in Indo-China. Recommendation 3 (d) of the Committee's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: That some uncertainty has arisen in ASEAN suggests to the Committee that Australia's regional policies have not been consistently propounded and explained as extensively as might be desirable. This makes consultation of prime importance. It is in both Australia's and ASEAN's interests to avoid major discord between them over policies towards regional security issues.
The report goes on to state:

The evidence does suggest, however, that if Australia wishes to take a consistent interest in the security of the Southeast Asian region overall, it will need to emphasise clearly that in seeking to explore ways of enhancing prospects for regional security the cautious development of policies towards Indo-China will not be pursued at the expense of long-term relations with ASEAN.

That is a very significant part of the Committee's report. The Minister flew in the face of the recommendations of that report in visiting Vietnam. In visiting that country he did all the things that the Committee report warned against. The report is all the more significant because it is a report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, a committee of both members of the Government and members of the Opposition. Too little attention is given in this House, in the media and in the community generally, to reports of Committees where both sides of the Parliament sit down in the community interest. This report is all the more significant for that, and it is even more significant that the Minister flew in the face of the all-party report.

As the previous speaker on this side has said, the Minister's trip to Indo-China was disastrous. It has upset ASEAN, our important neighbours, and it has upset its attitude to Australia. I believe it has endangered our foreign policy. The Minister's trip to Vietnam, at a time when Vietnamese troops were in Thailand, an ASEAN country, has endangered not only our relationship with Thailand but our relationship with ASEAN. The Minister's trip was naive and stupid and it flew in the face of the report of the Joint Committee of October last year. I find it surprising and amazing that the Minister for Foreign Affairs of this country would visit Vietnam at a time when Vietnamese troops were over the border of Thailand.

I conclude by looking at the human rights aspect of Vietnam. Vietnam has hundreds of thousands of people in so-called re-education camps, but which are actually concentration camps. That is an enormous denial of human rights in our region. I think the Minister's visit was a total disaster and, as I have said, flew in the face of the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) the Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ''the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The excessive hardship imposed on elderly Australians by the Government's assets test:
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is necessary for this matter of public importance to be raised again. It will be recalled that before the implementation of the assets test-in fact the day before the test-the Opposition brought up the matter to try to indicate to the Government the seriousness of the situation facing many elderly Australians, and many others who rely on the pension, because of the implications involved in that test. Halfway through the month following the introduction of the test the lessons from that debate have not been applied; nor has the review or monitoring promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), to keep a very close look on those people who are suffering these severe hardships, yet taken place. I am sure that Opposition members, in representing their electorates, have had quite a few examples given to them in the last three weeks-hundreds of examples in fact. Yet we hear the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) saying at Question Time that he has few representations on this matter. No doubt he has had few representations because the results of those representations that have been made to him have been pointless. Those who have seen me after the event say: 'Yes, he smiles nicely at us, he understands the situation, but as far as he is concerned there is no place in the social security system for someone who is assets rich but cash poor', and basically that is what we are talking about now.

SPEECH.PARA: We bring this matter before the House at a time when the Cabinet is discussing other changes in other systems and programs. One has only to mention the family allowance where the suggestion is that it should be flat rated. This will cause extreme difficulties to other people who are already relying on Government assistance to bring up big families. It is just one thing after another. It is obvious that the Minister has not applied any of the lessons that have been learnt. We have received the indications and there are many other indications of which the Minister should be aware.

I shall give an example of what happens in one average electorate in Australia in relation to the introduction of the assets test. This information was given in answer to a question on page 1332 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 17 April 1985. It indicates that in one electorate the number of pensions cancelled as a result of the assets test was 295-almost 300. These pensions are basically age pensions but they also include those of other groups who suffer from the assets test-invalids, widows, supporting parents, the whole lot of them. The number who had pensions reduced as a result of the assets test was 302. Even before the assets test was introduced, we heard the Minister's very selective sampling and we have heard it again today. He is trying to indicate how great the assets test has been in bringing to heel those members of the community who are abusing the system. There is no program in Australia at the moment that does not suffer some form of abuse. The Government that tries to remove that will have a very difficult job. For the Minister to quote selectively 12 millionaires who are getting the pension--

TALK.START.PARA: —It hurts, doesn't it?

—It does not hurt. I just want to remind the Minister that a person who, two years ago had he known what was ahead, invested $700,000 overseas in American currency would be a millionaire today in Australian currency. That is precisely the selective sampling the Minister has used.
—Should those people get the pension?

—Maybe, but I will go on to the other point: Why is the Minister able to quote selectively from what are obviously private records in a public sense just to demonstrate a point? One wonders, and this is what we have been asking all the time, what this saving is intended to lead to. If the Minister is prepared to use these examples publicly, I have no doubt that the Government will, in due course, use every valuation for an assets test for the purposes of a wealth tax, a death tax and the whole range of taxes. This is just the thin end of the wedge.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister mentioned that we were representing the privileged and the wealthy. I remind the Minister that over the last three days in this House it has been made quite obvious whom the Government is representing-that is the Australian Council of Trade Unions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Simon says.

—Yes, Simon says. The ACTU seems to have an input into these decisions well before anyone else in the nation and even before the Government itself. So the Minister should not talk to us about privilege without knowing where his own patronage falls.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give some examples that have been obvious to the Opposition and obviously the Government should have been made aware of them. After all, it is the Government's legislation. We are still getting complaints from Government members that it is the nasty people at the Department of Social Security offices who are to blame in implementing this test. It is not their fault at all. The Social Security Department's staff are doing the best they can under the circumstances without the flexibility of guidelines to administer the Act. The Minister and the Government are to blame for the assets test and the Australian people should never be allowed to forget it.

I will give just a few examples. Before the introduction of the assets test we heard of the case of a person in the urban area of Melbourne who had 2.2 hectares of land. Two hectares was accepted as curtilage for the house in which he resided. The other 0.2 of a hectare was of sufficient value to deprive that person of a pension. That is just one example.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had to sell his house?
—I do not know what he had to do.
—How else does he live?
—I can give you an example of the manner in which the Government--
—Order! I do not believe the interjections on my left are helping the speaker.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I would not like to disagree with you, but I would not like to feel that the people behind me were restrained. I now give an example of the situation when a sale is imminent. This is the situation in a sugar cane farming area where, as everybody knows, the valuations were pushed up over the last few years but have now shrunk to an all time low, to the extent that at this moment there is no way in the wide world that a person on an average farm with a 3,000 tonnes yield would be able to derive an income from that investment. However, that investment, on the basis of the assets test valuation, deprives the person of a pension. Perhaps the Minister thinks that is fair enough. That farm is being worked by the next generation of the family because they want to keep the farm in the family and they are not making an income. Obviously the owner of the farm, the pensioner parent, is not able to make an income either. They have sought to have that farm valued at the Valuer-General's valuation, or the lowest price at which that farm would sell at the moment. Honourable members should understand that we are talking in terms of liquidation and bankruptcy prices here. The farm is not being valued at its proper value. Its value is being pushed right up. The alternative for that person at the moment is to sell the farm, to put his son out of a job-the son is aged 45 or 50-and to put the son into the unemployment ranks. That is where it will end.
—And he will buy a big house.

—I do not know whether he will have enough money; he is a cane farmer. However, in another circumstance he might do that. In the case of a settlement following a divorce or family breakup there is now an obligation on the mother, if she wants to get a supporting parent's benefit and if she was previously in a business, to make a declaration that she will take no more income out of the partnership or business and thus deny herself benefits from the divorce settlement. Under this assets test that person has to sign a declaration before she receives one cent of pension.

SPEECH.PARA: An urban farm has been valued on the basis of its worth if it were subdivided and not at the value at which the pensioner who owns and wants to live on that farm would value it. That pensioner has no intention in mind but to retire on that farm, yet that farm has been valued at the urban value. What is the answer of honourable members opposite to that?

TALK.START.PARA: —What price would he sell it for?

—He is not going to sell it, you dumb idiot! I am telling you that he wants to stay on the farm and does not want to sell it. That is precisely the point to do with the assets test that this Government does not understand. This Government is forcing people to make alternative plans for retirement and is putting them on society's scrapheap. That is a direct result of this Government's assets test. The assets test is affecting pensioners in both Government-held and Opposition-held electorates.
—Ballarat, Bendigo-all the rural electorates.

—That is right. They are electorates that the Government will lose next election because the Government will find out that there is a limit to which it can push this part of the population without suffering the consequences. The Prime Minister made those promises about a review, but obviously those promises are going to be as helpful as his first promises-that there would be no alteration to the income test and that there would be no tax on superannuation. These massive programs have all taken place in the retirement area, of which the Government has no understanding. It is obvious the Government has not thought this through because already the promises made concerning the assets test-about social security inspectors on private premises and the gathering of information, and the statement that only 2 per cent of pensioners would be affected-are all out the back door.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic anomaly in the assets test is in the exemption of the house. It does not matter what the land is valued at. A person with a $250,000 house in inner Sydney can receive the full pension whereas a person on a rural farm worth that but with a house worth $50,000 does not receive it. That is the first anomaly.

I come to the other anomalies. During this last week the Minister has suggested to a couple in Tasmania who took their position to the media: 'What you ought to do is approach your local Social Security office first. The people there will tell you that there are hardship provisions under which you can apply; or, if you wish, you may borrow for the future and get the pension at 13 per cent'. I should like the Minister to tell me how many pensioners or past pensioners have taken advantage of the pay as you die scheme. I suggest they are very few. If that does not indicate something to the Minister, it should. The scheme is not a fair and reasonable scheme for a person to undertake. Why is that so? It is because they must sell everything first and provide some type of mortgage to secure the loan. That is point number one.

However, let us look at the hardship test. That is the real beauty. The Minister has said: 'The Social Security people are with you all the way; let them have a look at it'. The figures I have been given on this matter show that 1,268 appeals relating to hardship are pending at present. Of these, for Australia as a whole I believe that 23 have been granted-23 out of 1,200. What a miserable approach it is to ask a person to apply for hardship benefits when those conditions apply. To obtain hardship benefits, people have to prove that they have less than $5,000 in cash or that they have no acceptable assets to convert. The fact that people are asked to exclude from the exemption their motor cars, insurance policies, paintings and everything else makes me wonder whether a person who wants to get the hardship benefit should have to sell these things before he qualifies for the pension. As I understand it, a long term investment for a fixed term might have to be cashed, as might life assurance policies. Where is the equity in this system?

Recent statistics on this matter are just the tip of the iceberg. Five per cent of all those pensioners affected have lodged an appeal in some way or other. Some 2,433 pensioners have lodged such objections and, as I say, 629 have requested reviews, 536 have lodged appeals, and 1,268 have requested special consideration under the hardship provisions. One wonders how many more applications will come in.

I placed on notice the fact that I wanted to know how the appeals machinery was being set up to have these applications considered. The Minister answered last Wednesday, when he indicated that the number of appeals tribunals would not necessarily be increased. He said that the situation would be monitored. The interesting part is that under the present system, non-medical appeals take an average of 22.7 weeks to be heard and decided. Can a person aged 70 or 80 who is denied a pension and who has nothing available afford to wait for that period? I say no. As an Opposition, we are determined that the assets test will be scrapped. In saying that, however, we believe that the whole retirement areas should be closely examined so that the impact of income tax, superannuation, self-help schemes and universal schemes are tied in together to give Australians justice and equity. That has been denied to this small percentage of people, this 5 per cent. They may not be many, but they are human beings and Australians and they are deserving of the Parliament's concern and the Government's concern. That is what they have not received over the period of the assets test. I ask for reconsideration of the whole matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —One must ask the question: Whom does the honourable member wishto protect? I think it is very clear that one of the groups he wishes to protect is a group of millionaires. As I pointed out today, we have identified 12 millionaires as receiving the pension. SPEECH.PARA: I made the point earlier today that all members of the House have an obligation to recognise and understand that the social security system is essentially being directed towards people in need. Many would say that it ought to be directed to the people who are in most need. Some kind of means testing would be needed to achieve this objective. I do not think anyone in the House would suggest that there ought not be means testing. I indicated that historically means testing has been applied in two ways. On the one hand there has been income testing. On the other hand there has been some recognition that assets wealth mean and ultimately should be regarded as a source of income.

Income testing that is applied in respect of aged people, particularly those under 70 years of age, is extraordinarily strict. Indeed, a pensioner is allowed to have income of $30 a week before he loses a dollar of his pension. As I pointed out earlier in the House today, 1.5 million or 75 per cent of age pensioners in this country have declared incomes of less than $30 a week. The reality is that the overwhelming majority of pensioners are in that situation. No one is suggesting that that ought to be changed. I have received no representations that income testing in respect of the age pension ought to be eased.

The other type of means testing is the testing of people's assets. I want to make a point to the people who are pretending some concern and weeping crocodile tears about the assets test. Governments and oppositions during the long post-war period until 1976 supported the operation of an assets test. That assets test was administered by applying a 10 per cent valuation over and above the amount that was income tested. That amount was regarded as imputed additional income on top of actual income received. Those two amounts were put together. It is interesting to note that the family home and an extraordinarily small amount of money were excluded from that means test. I think at that time we were talking about a few hundred dollars. Now we are talking about some thousands of dollars that would be taken into account in relation to the assets test. So the assets test prior to 1976 was very stringent compared with the assets test today. It went alongside an incomes test which has always been very stringent.

The Opposition has come in today with this proposition in relation to the assets test which has nothing to do with fundamental directions and social policy in this country. I cannot understand how people whose responsibility, particularly when in opposition, is to think through the implications of long term social policy can say that they are opposed to this measure. Remember that the Leader of the Opposition said: 'I will abolish the assets test. I will get rid of it. I will go back to the situation prior to the introduction of the assets test'. But I ask honourable members opposite to think through what that will mean. It will mean that if someone has $1m or $500,000 in terms of a capital asset, he can carry on receiving a pension provided he does not turn it into income. It will mean that we will be paying to the supporting parents that the shadow Minister mentioned, who are the poorest group within the Australian community, a little bit less because we want to give those people in the community who are very wealthy relatively speaking, a little bit more! I ask the Opposition, when it comes in with propositions on this, to think through what it is saying in terms of social policy because I believe that what it is saying is absolute nonsense. It seems to me that amongst other things the Opposition, when it is in opposition, has an opportunity not simply to deal with things on the basis of short term political advantage but to do what is advocated by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), which is to think through what it is about in terms of substantial and long term policy questions.

I refer to two particular examples, as I have already done today, of people with assets over $1m. I do it certainly because it has a dramatic appeal but also because it takes us to the heart of the problem. The Opposition has to come to terms, in relation to means testing, with what is done in regard to someone who has very substantial assets and who has arranged his affairs so that he can minimise his income. I must say that I am not terribly impressed with the National Party of Australia because it is a party always there like a pig with its snout to the trough. It is always on about relative rural poverty and always on about how hard it is for people to-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. As a National Party member I take offence at being called a pig and I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—Order! I have considered the matter and it is really not a statement that should be withdrawn.

—The National Party is always advocating the need to spend additional government money. I think it is not unreasonable to ask the question of whether we are going to be paying people who have properties. A delegation from one rural area came to see me and I asked: 'What is the value of the properties which you are talking about; these people who are severely disadvantaged by the assets test?' I was told that the average valuation of properties in that particular area was $400,000. They brought along with them their accountant, who knew the intimate details, if I might say so, of the family circumstances. I said to them: 'Look, apart from the question of property, one of the rules in relation to the assets test is that we have to look at the amount of disposable income'. The accountant conceded that the people had on average-he was talking about the people who were part of a delegation from that rural area-$30,000 in liquid assets. I ask honourable members opposite: In terms of the needs of the two million or three million people in this country who are poor, what does one do in that situation, where someone has arranged his affairs so that he has very substantial assets but he is in circumstances where he has very minimal income? Do we disregard that property and that asset? Do we say that that person ought to be treated on the same basis as someone with virtually no income at all? It seems to me that members of the Opposition are so obsessed with scoring the odd point and with creating a ruckus in this place that they cannot think through the logic of their position. They have no position in relation to means testing because, if what the Leader of the Opposition promises is actually delivered, it would mean the beginning of the end of the means testing of pensions in this country. It simply is not credibly possible to go back to means testing only income, any more than it is possible to go back to a situation where the Government of the day, our Government, needed to take very strong measures to combat the realities of tax evasion and avoidance.

SPEECH.PARA: Fundamentally the conservative parties have to face up to this: Are they interested in an equitable social security system? If they are interested in an equitable social security system how are they going to deal with the reality of inequality of wealth, not only inequality of income? It is not possible in our community to achieve equity with respect to income without taking account of the realities of inequality of wealth.

I shall make a few points about the administration of the assets test. It is not true that representations are valueless and do not achieve change. I was able to inform the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) this afternoon that the case which he referred to me and which had had some publicity had been resolved by a revaluation. A very high percentage of the appeals-I shall not dispute the numbers suggested by the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) as I did not write them down-rests on the question of valuation, which needs to be addressed as a matter of urgency.

We are in some difficulty with valuations because of the kind of emotionalism which has been generated about Gestapo tactics, entering people's homes and all that rubbish. We sought to achieve valuation without a thorough inspection of people's property to protect that principle. We have now arrived at a method which, I believe, will enable us to review, through the Australian Taxation Office, valuations which people dispute. We are carrying out as rapidly as possible the investigation of cases under review about which there is dispute over the valuation. They are being reviewed by the Taxation Office, which will attempt to do that as quickly as possible. It is possible for that matter to be handled through that review process in consultation between the regional office and the Taxation Office without getting into the more extended appeal process. There is a review; there always has been. That is why I have written to honourable members today saying that, if they have cases, it is important that they refer them to me or that they take them up with their local regional office, so that if there is, for example, a question of valuation, that can be resolved as quickly as possible. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House and the nation should be advised of the importance of small business to the welfare of the community and to the welfare of the citizens of the seat of Deakin in Victoria. Many commentators, when writing of the condition of democratic capitalism in the late twentieth century, leave the impression that the bulk of the work force is employed in large organisations. In fact, less than one per cent of businesses in Australia employ 100 people or more; 99.4 per cent of firms employ less than 100 people; and less than one per cent employ between 50 and 99 people. Dickensian and vulgar Marxist notions of a world organised into vast, urban factory conglomerates have failed to materialise.

SPEECH.PARA: Facts such as these will not stop the Socialist Left faction of the Government parading its ritual fantasies, but that should make the rest of us aware of the importance of small and medium businesses to the national interest. The key fact is that 92 per cent of businesses in Australia employ less than 10 people. So much for Marx and his disciples.

In the light of these facts, what I propose is that a small business impact statement be attached to each government Act and regulation. The House will be astonished to learn that in the past 20 years the people of Australia and the firms where they work have been subjected to some 50,000 government Acts and regulations, and most of them are broken down into dozens of sections, sub-sections, wheretofores and the rest. Small business is unable to employ teams of company lawyers, chartered accountants and logicians on its staff to decipher all these rules and regulations. Small business has to get on with the job of producing the goods, servicing the market, paying its taxes and trying to meet the wages bill and insurance payments for workers compensation. The current situation in which small businesses are being drained of working capital by paying sales tax on revenue before they receive the revenue is a disgrace.

Most of the new jobs which have come onto the market in the past 10 years are in the small business area, but they have been created in spite of, rather than because of, the activities of government. I smile when I hear Government leaders piously claim that they have created jobs. They might just as well claim that they have created sunshine. It is now the practice of Federal governments to look at the financial impact of their Bills. I am suggesting that a small business impact statement should be made a matter of priority.

Let us look at some of the pieces of legislation before the House recently-the customs tariff proposals, the excise tariff proposals, the Bass Strait levy proposals, the Bounty (Injection Moulding) Bill and others. Each of these has a direct impact on a group of small businesses, or on all of them. There are potential costs in money and time in each of these pieces of legislation. There are investment consequences and, more importantly, there are consequences affecting jobs. Yet half of this Parliament would not have the faintest idea how their pet schemes, proposals and Bills affect small business and the jobs it creates. The Parliament needs to be told in clear terms of the impact of the Government's actions. From such knowledge a certain wisdom might grow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) delivered to this House statistics cleverly and selectively designed to suggest that Queensland's economy was at a dangerous ebb. Those figures were misleading, especially when one compares the statistical evidence over a more realistic period. There is no doubt that over a more relevant five-year period Queensland has been the fastest growing State in Australia. While several factors contributed to this growth, its main impetus was gained through the major once-off boost to the economy through the development of new export coal mines and port facilities. The major infrastructure associated with such work lifted Queensland's economy to a point where on all key indicators it was performing better than the national average. This is shown in the following figures, all of which relate to average annual growth rates for the five-year period from 30 June 1979 to 30 June 1984: Queensland's population grew at a rate of 2.3 per cent compared with a national average of 1.4 per cent; Queensland's labour force grew at a rate of 3.4 per cent, compared with a national average of 2 per cent; employment in Queensland grew at a rate of 2.8 per cent compared with a national average of 1.4 per cent; new fixed capital expenditure by private enterprises grew by 16 per cent in Queensland compared with a national average of 11.6 per cent, which was a four-year period only; the value of new buildings approved grew by 16.9 per cent in Queensland compared with a national average of 12.5 per cent; motor vehicle registrations grew by 5.3 per cent in Queensland compared with a national average of 3.7 per cent; and retail sales grew by 12 per cent in Queensland compared with a national average of 10.8 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: While Queensland's growth over the last five years has been spectacular, the current economic situation in Queensland reflects unfavourable national and international factors. This also has to be coupled with the completion of the expansion of Queensland's mineral developments. Despite the temporary problems we are currently facing, the underlying economic and financial strength of Queensland provides a sound basis for steady growth in the longer term. These growth prospects are enhanced by the Queensland Government's positive policy of encouraging economic development through expansion of the private sector. The current economic situation in Queensland is influenced by two main factors-the completion of the expansion phase of Queensland's massive coal resources, and the world economic situation, especially with regard to sugar and base metals. The effect of the completion of mining and port facilities was anticipated. However, the simultaneous problems in the world sugar market and low world prices for base metals, particularly copper, compounded the effect on Queensland's economic growth. Long term benefits are now being achieved through increased revenues and job opportunities associated with the operational phase. However, it was always accepted that the level of economic expansion would, inevitably, return more to the Australian average, although on a considerably improved base.

It is in this context that Queensland's current level of economic performance must be assessed. The key point is that while many of our current economic indicators are below their previous high levels, they are still above the national average. They are above the contribution to Australia's performance that could be expected on the basis of population share. Compared with our population share of 16.1 per cent, the latest figures show that Queensland contributes 17.4 per cent of new fixed capital expenditure by private enterprises; 24.5 per cent of housing completions and 23 per cent of all building completions in Australia; and 23.7 per cent of Australia's exports. These are positive indicators of the State's growth and potential.

One of the sources of major growth in the economy of Queensland, and Australia, in the future will continue to be our vast mineral resources. These include about 50 per cent of Australia's proven recoverable reserves of coal, bauxite, silver, lead and zinc. Recent studies of our international competitiveness in coal and aluminium confirm that our substantial cost advantages will ensure a prominent position in international markets as demand expands.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate this opportunity to speak in the adjournment debate today. I would like to turn to the assets test to look at some of the points raised by members of the Opposition in their speeches on the adjournment during the week. We on the Government side have said time and again that the assets test will bring back to the retirement system in Australia the fairness lacking after it was taken away in 1976 by the former Government. What many people do not realise is that we had an assets test in Australia from 1908 to 1976. It is very difficult to measure need on an income test alone. If we do that we open up a new field of endeavour for accountants to manipulate money in such a way that people can become assets rich and income poor. Those people who care to check the Pensioner's News, in the years around 1980 to 1982 in particular, will find many schemes being marketed. Full page advertisements advised pensioners with considerable assets to go to these accountancy firms so that they could arrange their assets in such a way that they would get the full pension and the benefits. The Government has rightly recognised that pensions are meant only for those people in need. 'Need' is the operative word. By bringing back the assets test we are able to have a look at the retirement income system in a much fairer way than was possible before its abolition.

SPEECH.PARA: One thing a lot of people do not realise-it was made obvious in Question Time today-is that it is not compulsory to fill out an assets test form. There is no compulsion whatsoever. The only time that one has to fill out an assets form is when one wants a pension. I have stated before on many occasions, in Western Australia anyway, that I do not believe that Alan Bond or Lang Hancock will ever fill out an assets test form, mainly because they do not need a pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't get the pension.

—Of course they do not need a pension. Another thing about the pension is that it is meant only for people in need. The policy of a former Menzies Government was that people should provide for their own retirement. To that Government's credit, it allowed a tax deduction to encourage people to look after their retirement income by taking out superannuation policies. In Australia today those superannuation policies can be taken as a lump sum payment, invested in the schemes that I spoke about before that are being advertised in papers such as the Pensioner's News, and then a person can get a pension. What we are getting is double dipping.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government moved early in its term of office to close that avenue by bringing in a substantial tax disincentive for people taking lump sums. However, we have allowed people to have a tax-free status if those superannuation payments were taken, as they were meant to be, on a weekly or fortnightly basis. That is what superannuation is all about. It is all about looking after oneself in retirement.

In the short time available to me I would like to bring up the quite emotive cases, which are often brought up in this House, concerning those people who are hard done by as a result of the assets test. We have never said that the assets test would be easy to administer and that it would cover all cases. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) has made a point of ensuring that the assets test investigations are given the highest priority. We are working towards making sure that nobody is greatly disadvantaged by the assets test. It will take time. I imagine that, in a year's time, honourable members opposite will not be able to make the claims that they make today because of that. The Opposition parties' tactics in the last Federal election campaign can only be described as scandalous. The only reason that pensioners were scared was because of the opportunistic scaremongering tactics of the Opposition, and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in particular. He had nothing else to fly with except the assets test. I suppose that, in electoral terms, he was successful in that he was able to claim a mandate.

I would like to finish on this point: The Liberal Party of Australia has been talking about repealing the assets test if it gets back into government. All it has to do is answer one question: If it repeals the assets test, will it tell the people of Australia that it will raise taxes to give pensions to the wealthiest 2 per cent of the pensioners who do not need them, including the 12 millionaires the Minister talked about today, or will it lower the pension for the other people who really need it? That is the question that must be addressed if the Opposition is going to start talking about repealing the assets test. If members of the Opposition ever talk about it at the next election campaign, we will hammer that point as hard as we can. It is a significant point and they have never answered the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tasmania has a proud record of looking after its beautiful scenery and natural wilderness areas. I illustrate that by making the point that Tasmania has over three times the percentage of national parks of any other State in Australia and, in some cases, it has six times the percentage. In addition, 23 per cent of the State has already been nominated for the register of the National Estate. Recently people have been working to have more parts of the State registered. These parts now total 31 per cent of that State. People on the mainland should realise that that is the equivalent of all the area of Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria being on a national register.

SPEECH.PARA: Once land is registered that prevents any person from investing in that part of the country. If companies want to mine or enter into any other venture, such as in the timber industries, they know that they will be in for long delays in dealing with government departments and working out whether they can undertake commercial activities in those areas. If people on the mainland had as large a proportion of the land as that cut out of economic activity I believe people would be seriously outraged. Because this land is in Tasmania people on the mainland believe what is in the newspapers or what is in articles written in nice glossy magazines such as the one put out by the Wilderness Society or the Forest Action Network people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen what the timber industry puts out?
—Look at some of the photos in it.
—That is exactly what I am going to do. This magazine includes a photograph showing where the logging contractors loaded the logs onto their trucks. The sentence under the photograph states:

SPEECH.PARA: This logging landing represents an area lost to production forestry because of major soil compaction and disturbance . . .

The Wilderness Society uses this sort of photograph to sell to other people the idea that a forest will never be grown in that area again. I know from experience and from knowing areas where logging contractors have worked that it takes only five or eight years to get eucalypt trees growing there again. They are usually 15 to 20 feet tall within five years, even though hundreds of cubic metres of logs have been loaded in a small area and the soil has been compacted. Anybody in this Parliament who understands the forces of nature will realise that even things like mushrooms will push their way through cement paths.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fair go! Through the cracks, perhaps, but not the cement paths.

—The honourable member should look at his botany books and he will find those examples. They do exist. The implication by the Wilderness Society is that just because the ground has been compacted it will not grow a forest again, even if it is allowed to. That is utter nonsense. Forests do grow back. That does happen, it has happened and it will continue to happen. Lots of other illustrations in this magazine are just as ludicrous. The comment appearing under another photograph states:

SPEECH.PARA: Logging debris pushed into creek. Riparian ecosystem totally destroyed . . .

That is also total nonsense because what will happen there is that that ecosystem will regenerate in another way. That has been going on for thousands and thousands of years. The ecosystem that exists anywhere at any time is probably not the same ecosystem that existed a thousand years previously. To say that that ecosystem is totally destroyed is nonsense. It will just change into something else over a period.

What really needs to happen is that instead of having people who can register areas on the National Estate and can lock up resources in any part of Australia without the people of that State knowing-particularly the Government, the Premier or the Parliament-we have to have a good look at this matter and change the situation. This has been an emotional issue. As we develop as a nation I hope that some common sense can come into this matter rather than these people being allowed to lock up our nation's resources.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise, first of all, to remind the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) about the subscriber trunk dialling problem which is prevalent in the Frankston area. Ever since I have been a member of this House we have been pushing for STD rates to be removed from a small area within the Dunkley electorate. People may not believe it but parts of Frankston are still on the 059 network. There is an area down there called Mt Eliza which is on the 03 network. It is called the Mt Eliza bulge. It does not come within the radius which is drawn by Telecom Australia, but it bulges out and happens to go right down and cover Mt Eliza and Mornington. SPEECH.PARA: I also must mention the Palm Sunday march which I attended recently and in which I was proud to take part. This march was attended by thousands of people, many of whom were young people. This is important, and it augurs well for the peace movement. I am also proud to be a member of People for Nuclear Disarmament. It has taken several years for this movement to build up, and I have been a member for many years. I had a business of my own called CND Industries. It was not named CND Industries for any real political reasons, it was just to remind those people who were involved in or had some knowledge of the peace movement that I was actively engaged in trying to promote it for many years. Some parts of the peace movement supposedly belong to one particular faction. That is not correct, it crosses all factional groups, and I am proud to be a member of the peace movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you have any anti-Russian banners?

—Yes, there were many anti-Russian banners. There were banners complaining against Russian build up of nuclear arms as well as the American build up of nuclear arms. This is something that many people in the House do not realise because they have never got off their backsides to take part in a movement such as that.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet I must also discuss, as a member of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, the matter of woodchipping which was raised by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles). I have that booklet. I have never been to the south-west of Tasmania but I have seen photographs. I believe what I see in some of those photographs, and it is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go and have a look then.
—I will be. It is a disgrace. The Tasmanians have a beautiful island there.
—Would you lock up 30 per cent of your electorate?

—The honourable member says that we should lock up 30 per cent of it. What other nation in the world is rich enough to be able to do that? What will it be like in the future, when people come to Australia and go to Tasmania to see that area in its natural state? That area will draw tourists from all over the world. Tasmanians do not realise the potential they have. They want to rip it all out with bulldozers and push it into creeks. Of course it will wreck the environment.
—Would you lock up 30 per cent of your electorate?

—I would be pleased to do it if it was in its natural state. It is not; it is covered by concrete and houses and things like that. That is wrong. More of it should be left in its natural state. Tasmanians have a magnificent asset and they are just going to destroy it, chop it down and turn it into pulp so that we can have great stacks of paper. That is a disgrace. They should not do that; they should protect this area for future generations instead of turning it into wood chips. Some of the people who are interjecting here are very good at exploiting our natural resources. Instead of those resources belonging to the people of Australia, their companies exploit them and sell them off to the world.
—How many trees have you planted?

—I have planted lots of trees. If the honourable member comes to the shopping centre near where I live he will see where I instigated the planting of the trees around it. It has made a tremendous difference.
—How many?

—I would say about 50. That is probably 50 more than the honourable member has ever planted. While I am talking about the Tower Hill shopping centre, I must say how good the shopkeepers are because they look after all the trees. In the Frankston central business district, the Bayside shopping centre has been bought by the Gandel Group. It has put up the rents of the small shopkeepers by 400 per cent, which is a disgrace.
