TALK.START.PARA: —Throughout this week we have heard a great deal in this House about the situation in Queensland which has culminated in today's strike, a disgusting event, and members of the Australian Labor Party ought to be hanging their heads in shame. In Tasmania we sympathise with what is happening in Queensland, but whilst the blockade in Queensland has been going on we have had similar industrial trouble in Tasmania. The Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia is currently holding the Tasmanian economy to ransom. The current strike by the FEDFA is motivated purely by political considerations, as is the case in Queensland, and has nothing at all to do with industrial relations. The strike is attacking the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills plant at Longreach in my electorate and on the east coast of Tasmania at Triabunna in the electorate of Lyons, held by Mr Burr.

SPEECH.PARA: The strike began some three weeks ago. The FEDFA defied an order by a commissioner of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. An article on the front page of today's Launceston Examiner is headed: 'Union ''Out to Destroy Trade'' '. Commissioner McKenzie is reported to have said that it appeared to him that the FEDFA was hell-bent on destroying Australia's vital woodchip industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of those blokes earns $43,000 a year net.

—Did honourable members hear that, $43,000 net a year? The consequence of the strike has been the standing down of workers at the Longreach and Triabunna mills. The dispute has already cost $2m and has led to 800 forestry workers now being without a job.

SPEECH.PARA: Before discussing the political motivation of strikes and the supporters of strikes, let me outline the brief history of this action which is so damaging the Tasmanian economy. The record of the FEDFA since 1982 is both miserable and shameful. In the last three years it has held nearly a strike a month. Over 3,500 workers have had to be stood down in three years because of the thugs in this union and other associated unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's not right.
—It is true. But what really motivates me to speak today is the callous manner and political motivation of these disputations.
—The unions have been bashing the community for years.
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin has had his opportunity to speak in the adjournment debate.
—I think he is contributing very well, Mr Speaker.
—I suggest to the honourable member for Bass that he not take over the functions of the Chair.

—The sad part is that many strikes are politically motivated. Equally true is the fact that many supporters of strikes are politically motivated. Let me give the House two examples of such blatant political posturing. A recently elected Labor senator from my State-Terry Aulich, the failed State Minister for Industrial Relations and the failed, rejected and discredited State Minister for Education-went to Queensland to tell the Queensland Government how to run its State. John Devereux, a thoroughly discredited and rejected candidate in the December Federal election, who thankfully lost to my colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), was arrested yesterday in Queensland. He plans to stand at the next State election. He is State President of the ALP and a member of the left wing, a faction without any credibility in my State or indeed in this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Those two members of the Labor Party, both rejected at elections in my State in the past three years, now traverse the nation masquerading as industrial relations experts. In truth, neither has any expertise in this area and both operate merely for political gain and political exposure. They are prepared to sell out industrial order around the nation in order to enhance further their own paltry political careers. Both men have been conspicuous by their silence on the current industrial lawlessness in my State, and for this they stand condemned in this Parliament and in my home State of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three weeks ago I was privileged, as part of an Australian delegation, to attend a United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation conference on adult education. This is the third such conference on adult education that UNESCO has sponsored over the last 30 years. Of late there has been some criticism of UNESCO. Unfortunately, most of this criticism is ill-informed, mischievous and misleading. I actually saw UNESCO in action. I was one of the delegates from some 100 countries discussing problems of great relevance to their countries. Many of the developing countries have a great problem in adult education. A growing problem is literacy. Other countries, such as Australia, have a problem with how to deal with a post-industrial society. It is not just the holding of this conference but the exchange of ideas at UNESCO that fosters international goodwill. Having experienced UNESCO in action, I am pleased with the role that Australia has played, especially the contribution under the leadership of the current Ambassador. No one would suggest that the performance of UNESCO should never be reviewed.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Hague Conference on Civil Aspects of International Child Abductions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the answers to my questions No. 3992 (Hansard, 21 August 1979, page 382) and No. 5609 (Hansard, 8 December 1982, page 3227) concerning the Hague conference on Civil Aspects of International Child Abductions, can the Attorney-General now say when legislation will be introduced in Australia to ratify the Convention.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) the convention provides for the return of children who have been wrongfully abducted to other countries and (b) this problem has become increasingly pressing in recent years.
(3) Can the Attorney-General say which other countries have ratified or intend to ratify the Convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is expected that Regulations pursuant to section 111B of the Family Law Act 1975 will be made this year to give effect to the requirements of the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction. Australia will then be in a position to ratify the Convention.
(2) (a) The Convention provides for the return of children wrongfully abducted between member countries. (b) No precise figures on the incidence of child abduction are available.

(3) To date four countries, France, Canada, Switzerland and Portugal, have ratified the convention. These ratifications have brought the Convention into operation. At the 15th Session of the Hague Conference on Private International Law held from 8-20 October 1984, a number of other countries, including Australia, indicated that they were taking action with a view to ratifying the Convention. The United States, Belgium, Greece, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom have signed the Convention.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports published in the Courier-Mail of 10, 11, 14, 15, 16 and 27 December 1984 and on 1 January 1985 and in the Sun-Herald of 20 and 27 January 1985 concerning statements made by Mr Graham Pike, President of the recently formed Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation, concerning the consideration by the Government of increased taxes on fishing equipment and fuel for boats; if so, is he able to confirm the accuracy of these statements.

(2) Is Mr Graham Pike, President of the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation, the same Mr Graham Pike, Director of Public Relations for the Department of Primary Industry; if so, will he assure recreational fishing interests that there will be no conflict in statements or actions by Mr Pike, should any dispute arise between the Government and the sporting group, as happened in 1979 with the Japanese longline controversy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the media reports concerning the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation to which the honourable member for Fadden refers but as has been clearly pointed out in a letter in the Courier-Mail on 27 December 1984 from Mr Graham Pike, President of the Confederation the media reports and letters critical of the Confederation and Mr Pike were based on one, initial article published on the front-page of the Courier-Mail on 10 December 1984. As Mr Pike stated, that initial article was inaccurate and misleading and it is fundamentally wrong to suggest, as the first article did, that the Government is considering increased taxes on recreational fishers.

(2) In a second letter in the Courier-Mail on 30 January 1985, the Confederation President, Mr Pike, stated that he was also Director of Public Relations for the Department of Primary Industry. He made it clear in that letter that no conflict of interest exists between his employment in the Department of Primary Industry and his role as President of the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation. The Department of Primary Industry has no jurisdiction over recreational fishing and I am informed that Mr Pike's official duties are not connected with fishing policy or funding. Mr Pike's involvement with recreational fishing is extremely well known within the Department, to the industry and the general public and the likelihood of a conflict of interest arising under such circumstances is extremely remote and in any case, would be dealt with through existing administrative provisions, of which Mr Pike is well aware.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he or his Department make a grant to the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation or to its President, Mr Graham Pike, to stage a meeting in Brisbane on or about 9 December 1984; if so, what was the amount of the grant.
(2) For what specific purposes or expenditure was the grant made.

(3) Was part of the purpose of this meeting to keep in touch with individuals and organisations in the States; if so, why were the President and Secretary of the Queensland Amateur Fishing Council, representing amateur fishermen in that State, refused entry to the meeting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) There was no specific grant made.

(3) The Australian Recreational Fishing Conference is comprised of the seven national organisations representing the various types of recreational fishing and fishing interests. It is therefore a peak national body, autonomous under its constitution and I am not involved in its internal workings. This being so, I do not know of the circumstances surrounding the meetings of the Confederation Executive in Brisbane in December last year. I do note, however, that in his letter in the Courier-Mail of 30 January 1985, the Confederation President states that the Chairman and Secretary of the Queensland Amateur Fishing Council did attend at the time of the Brisbane meeting and spent several hours in discussions of mutual interest with the Confederation executive. It may interest the honourable member to know that I have been informed that the Confederation is currently giving very active consideration to creating an associate membership category in its constitution which would include State and Territory organisations representing recreational fishing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he or his Department authorise a press release foreshadowing increased federal taxes on fishing equipment and boat fuel, following a meeting of the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation in Brisbane, on or about 9 December 1984.
(2) Did he or his Department have informal or formal discussions with the President of that Confederation regarding proposed tax increases prior to the meeting.
(3) Have discussions regarding the subject been undertaken between him or his Department and the Department of Primary Industry or the Minister for Primary Industry.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to a letter to the Courier-Mail, dated 13 December 1984, from Mr Graham Pike, President of the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation, which states that the Confederation was constituted earlier in 1984, and is supported strongly by the Commonwealth Government; if so, does he endorse this view.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (4) The Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation was formed in response to the need to have a unified national body representing Australia's recreational fishers-and as a Confederation survey has shown, there are some five million of them. Fishing, according to the survey, is Australia's biggest outdoor sport, contributing in excess of $2.2 billion a year to the Australian economy. That is a very big industry and has obvious significant ramifications for tourism as well as for the healthy and wholesome outdoor life of millions of Australians. This Government has recognised the national importance of fishing as a sport and outdoor past-time and actively supported the formation of the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation which is greatly assisting in fishing's development. The Government is continuing, through the Australian Sports Commission, to support the Confederation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he or his Department make a grant of $50,000 to the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation for the purpose of commissioning a survey of recreational fishing in Australia.
(2) Were tenders called for consultants to conduct the survey; if so (a) who were the tenderers (b) what were the tender amounts and (c) who was the successful tenderer.
(3) How was $50,000 arrived at as being a suitable sum for such a survey.
(4) Has he authorised the Confederation to sell copies of the results of the survey to other recreational fishing organisations; if so, for what purpose will the income from these sales be used.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. A grant of $50,000 over two financial years was made to the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation as part of the Government's programs of assistance to national sporting and recreational organisations.

(2) As I stated in my response to Question 43, I am not involved, nor should I be, in the internal workings of organisations such as the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation but the Confederation has freely provided the Australian Sports Commission with the information the honourable member seeks. I am advised that the Confederation did ask for tenders for the national recreational fishing survey and received proposals from Market Survey Centre Pty Ltd, McNair Anderson Associates Pty Ltd, PA Management Consultants, and the Roy Morgan Research Centre Pty Ltd. Some of the proposals were given in confidence and for commercial reasons too, the Confederation feels that the prices quoted should not be attached to the names of particular tenderers. The prices quoted by firms meeting all the specifications ranged from $50,000 to $128,000. The successful tenderer was PA Management Consultants.

(3) The Confederation commissioned PA Management Consultants after extensive discussions, about cost-effectiveness and other technical matters relating to the proposed survey, with appropriate officers of my Department. Through my Department, the Australian Bureau of Statistics was also consulted. The Confederation, of course, also sought and received advice from other sources on the matter before making a decision.

(4) As a properly constituted, autonomous body, the Australian Recreational Fishing Confederation is free to run its affairs as it sees fit and does not require any Ministerial authorisation for the conduct of its activities under its constitution.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 22 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With regard to recommendation 12 of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure of November 1983 entitled 'The Way We P(l)ay', did the Government in fact clarify the objectives and scope of the inaugural Australia Games before committing Commonwealth funding, if so when and where.

(2) What was the Government's total financial commitment to, and in connection with, these Games, including appropriations through the Sports Development Program, the International Standard Sports Facilities Program, or through any other program or appropriation, either direct or indirect.

(3) What is the precise financial and administrative relationship between the Government and (a) the Australian Games Foundation, (b) the Australia Games Board of Management and (c) the Australia Games Organising Committee.

(4) What were the financial results of the Games, itemised by income from (a) marketing and sponsorship of the Games, (b) ticket sales, (c) the sale of television rights and (d) any other relevant item.
(5) What was the total expenditure incurred by the Australia Games Foundation itemised by relevant categories.
(6) Is he able to say whether the Games were a financial success.
(7) What overseas countries participated at the Games, and how many participants attended from each country.
(8) How many Federal Ministers attended the Games.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 13 September 1984 I tabled in the Parliament the Government's response to the recommendations contained in the McLeay report. In that response I advised that the Australia Games Foundation had clarified the scope and objectives of the Games. These are as published in my Department's 1983-84 annual report. As a result, the Government agreed to provide $800,000 to support the Australia Games in Melbourne.

(2) The Government's financial commitment to the Australia Games can be categorised in three ways. First, direct assistance to Games costs for which $800,000 was provided in 1984-85. Secondly, direct administrative assistance to the Australia Games Foundation from the Sports Development Program consisting of grants of $50,000 in 1981-82, $180,000 in 1982-83, $60,000 in 1983-84 and $100,000 in 1984-85. Assistance in 1981-82, 1982-83 and 1983-84 related to the Games Foundation's endeavours to establish the inaugural Australia Games in Sydney in January 1984.

The third category relates to facility development under the then International Standard Sports Facilities Program where $500,000 ($89,500 in 1983-84 and $410,500 in 1984-85) was provided on a dollar-for-dollar basis with the Victorian Government to upgrade the Olympic Park Athletics Track.

(3) The extent of Commonwealth financial support for the Australia Games is indicated in the answer (2) above. (a) The Australia Games Foundation was registered on 10 March 1983, under the Companies Act 1961 (Victoria), as an incorporated company limited by guarantee. (b) The Commonwealth has two representatives on the Australia Games Board of Management. (c) The Commonwealth also provided two representatives on the Australia Games Organising Committee which was established by the Board of Management, in consultation with the Victorian Government, to organise the Games in Melbourne from 26 January to 3 February 1985.

(4), (5) and (6) At this stage, because individual sporting organisations have yet to complete audited financial statements in respect of each event conducted and provide them to the Australia Games Foundation, it is too early to provide a final summary of the Games expenditure and revenue budget. Audited financial statements are to be consolidated by the Foundation and will include revenue still coming into the Foundation's account. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Awarding of Costs in Criminal Cases in the Australian Capital Territory

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Has he or his Department sent a direction to magistrates in the Australian Capital Territory suggesting that they should order costs to follow the event in criminal cases; if so, what is the wording of this instruction.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is:

ANSWER.PARA: Neither I nor my Department have given an instruction to magistrates in the Australian Capital Territory suggesting that they should order costs to follow the event in criminal cases.

In June 1984, following representations by the Law Society of the Australian Capital Territory seeking clarification of the policy of the Deputy Crown Solicitor in claiming costs in criminal proceedings, my predecessor identified a number of categories of cases where costs would not be sought as exceptions to a general rule of seeking costs in every case where the informant was successful. The categories are:
(A) Courts of Petty Sessions
(i) in undefended matters disposed of in the general list on the first or second return date of the summons
(ii) committal proceedings and trials upon indictment in the Supreme Court
(iii) where the defendant is required to undergo a jail sentence and it is unlikely that he would be in a position to pay
(iv) in cases where because of poverty, extreme hardship or other special circumstances, it would not be appropriate to seek an order for costs.
(B) Superior Courts
(i) proceedings on indictment in the Supreme Court
(ii) appeals whether against conviction or sentence emanating from trials on indictment.

Responsibility for prosecution work in the Australian Capital Territory has since passed to the Director of Public Prosecutions. He has initiated a review of the above- stated policy. The review is being conducted by the Deputy Director of Public Prosecutions in the Australian Capital Territory, Mr R. Greenwood QC. The Director of Public Prosecutions will be advising me on the completion of the review.

My predecessor also asked officers of my Department to approach the Chief Magistrate in the Australian Capital Territory with the object of establishing an appropriate schedule of costs to be applied in Petty Sessions prosecution matters which schedule would eliminate any inconsistencies between magistrates in the amount of costs they award in prosecution matters.
The approach to the Chief Magistrate is being held in abeyance pending Mr Greenwood QC completing his review of the abovestated policy.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Fitness Survey of Secondary School Children

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 28 February 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What control will he or his Department exercise over the expenditure of the $300,000 contribution to the survey to be carried out by the Australian Council for Health, Physical Education and Recreation (ACHPER) to test the fitness of Australian schoolchildren.
(2) What are the proposed contribution details of this survey, in particular the cost of administering this survey.
(3) Were tenders called for consultants to conduct this survey; if so, who were the tenderers and what were the tender amounts.
(4) What facilities does ACHPER have to conduct a survey of this kind.
(5) How was $300,000 arrived at as being a suitable amount to contribute to such a survey.
(6) What is the anticipated scope and duration of the survey.
(7) How many people will be involved both full-time and part-time in conducting the survey.

(8) Why has he endorsed a new survey of fitness in Australian schoolchildren despite his stated concern that there has been little improvement in the fitness levels of secondary students since the last survey.
(9) What evidence is there available prior to this new survey which would warrant the introduction of national fitness awards to encourage Australian schoolchildren to raise their fitness level.
(10) Why has he authorised his Department to contribute to the survey if the awards are going to be introduced in any case.
(11) Will he direct the $300,000 to be spent directly on incentives to improve the fitness of schoolchildren.
(12) Has he or his Department earmarked any funds for the proposed series of national fitness awards: if so, what amount.
(13) What is the evidence to suggest that the introduction of fitness awards will encourage a general lift in fitness levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As is normal procedure, the Australian Council for Health, Physical Education and Recreation (ACHPER) is required, under the conditions of acceptance of the grant, to provide my Department with audited expenditure statements indicating that funds have been used for the purposes approved. In addition, my Department is represented on ACHPER's project management committee to provide expert advice and to monitor progress on the implementation of the project.
(2) The total budget for the conduct of the survey is in the vicinity of $500,000. The major costs in the survey are expected to be:
personnel $269,000 (refer to answer to part 7)
laboratory tests $30,000
equipment $75,500
travel $43,000
administration and overheads $20,000
computing $30,000
preparation of report and printing $15,000

My Department is contributing $300,000 and ACHPER has succeeded in attracting support from a range of other government agencies and private sponsors which have an interest in these areas, including the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Department of Health.

(3) Tenders were not called. The project has been a joint Commonwealth/ACHPER exercise developed over the last 5-6 years and involved funding from the Menzies Foundation for a proposal entitled 'Recommended Guidelines and Protocols for the Establishment of a National Fitness, Health and Physical Performance Survey in Australian Schools' which formed the basis of the current survey. Tenders were not called in view of ACHPER's long involvement in the development of the project and its experience in the promotion of physical education in the schools.

(4) ACHPER is the only Australian professional organisation for physical educators, health educators, recreation personnel, dance and fitness leaders. It is an incorporated body whose national office is located in Adelaide. ACHPER has a small staff of professional and clerical officers and a membership of more than 2,000 professionals who bring to the project the benefits of extensive liaison networks with the schools (where the survey is to be conducted), educational and tertiary institutions and other specialised professional groups. For the purpose of the survey ACHPER has established a national survey office in Canberra. ACHPER has demonstrated on many occasions its capacity to undertake significant projects in this area, for example the Daily Physical Exercise program for children which is now in use throughout Australia and in many overseas countries, and the Jump Rope for Heart program currently conducted at a national level in conjunction with the National Heart Foundation.

(5) In its submission to me ACHPER identified a total of $300,000 required to finance the tests which are to be conducted over a six month period throughout Australia by a number of specially employed personnel, will comprise laboratory, technical and field tests and will involve the use of special equipment. As the results of the survey will have major impact on that area of my portfolio concerned with the development of policies on physical fitness, I considered it appropriate to provide that level of assistance in the knowledge that the balance of funds required would be found from other sources.

(6) The survey which is to be conducted nationwide has as its target schoolchildren between the ages of seven and fifteen years. The survey will be conducted in an equal number of primary and high schools (108 in all) across the States and Territories which were selected from a sample provided by the Australian Council for Educational Research and will involve a total of 9,000 children (20 randomly selected from each age in each school). The survey, including planning and the preparation of the report, will be carried out from March 1985 to March 1986, with the testing in schools being conducted between May and October 1985.
(7) The conduct of the survey will involve the employment by ACHPER of various categories of personnel:
one full-time project co-ordinator to be employed over a period of twelve months

77 persons (selected from unemployed and relief teachers and physical education graduates who will be trained in appropriate data collection techniques) to be employed full time over periods from 3 weeks to 3 months to collect data in the schools
1 full-time nurse to be employed over a period of 9 months
1 part-time typist
5 to 6 part-time data coders.

ACHPER will provide two specialised consultants and a Project Director and will assume all usual employer responsibilities. The Project Co-ordinator, who has responsibility for scientific and technical supervision of the project, has considerable experience in the gathering and analysis of physiological data.

(8) It is now over ten years since the publication of the results of the last major national survey of schoolchildren's fitness. It is important to identify changes in levels of fitness which may have taken place given the relatively slow development of organised physical education as a core component of school curricula, especially at the primary school level, during that time. Surveys that have been conducted in the interim, while of indicative value, have been restricted in scope, regional nature, range of parameters tested and the extent to which those surveys can be generalised to other groups. The conduct of a national survey using comprehensive testing methods such as is proposed by ACHPER will provide substantial information about the condition of schoolchildren's health, fitness and physical performance. This data will be the basis for the consideration and development by Governments and professional organisations of appropriate programs and strategies to promote and maintain levels of health and physical fitness. The survey to be conducted by ACHPER will be more comprehensive in its population base than the Willee survey which was confined to secondary schools and will also use a broader set of testing methods.

(9) and (10) The introduction of a National Fitness Award Scheme is an ACHPER initiative. I strongly support it in principle. The aim of such an Award Scheme is to offer incentives in the form of awards to increase levels of health and fitness.

(11) Incentives are currently provided to children and the community through the Department's general fitness programs including the staging of the First World Week of Physical Fitness and Sport for all events and activities in the first week of October 1985.

(13) National fitness award schemes in operation in the USA since 1966 and Canada since 1970 have proven to be highly successful. Both schemes operate under a supervised award system conducted in conjunction with the schools. The success of those programs can be indicated by the participation rates they have achieved, with as many as 2,000,000 in the USA scheme and nearly one third of all Canadian children involved.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Supply of Departmental Handbooks to Members of Parliament

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 19 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that the policy of the Australian Government Publishing Service provides for a free issue of departmental handbooks to members of parliament but not the loose leaf binder that goes with them; if so, why?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: AGPS does not provide free issues of copies of departmental handbooks to members of parliament. In most cases, these publications are produced in-house and distributed by individual departments. In cases where AGPS publishes such handbooks or manuals and they are provided for sale to the public, members of parliament may obtain up to two copies by provision of identification to AGPS bookshops. These copies are paid for by the Parliament. Where AGPS produces or arranges provision of binders with loose leaf publications, binders are provided with copies of these publications. In some instances, purchasers have the option of buying such publications with or without a binder. On occasions, client departments do not request provision of binders with loose leaf publications. In these cases, the publications are available only in the form ordered by clients. Similarly reprints or revised editions are often provided without a binder as users still have binders provided with the original edition. Production of special binders in these cases is uneconomic in that there is very little demand and, if produced as an integral part of the publication, impose an unattractive loading to the sale price. Consideration has been given to the sale of a range of plain modestly priced ring binders through AGPS bookshops. However, this would be a duplication of services already widely available through commercial stationers.
